Political loyalty or alignment should never substitute for scientific qualifications, as doing so would erode the credibility and integrity of publicly funded research programs.

Furthermore, current federal civil service regulations already enforce merit system principles, as codified in 5 U.S.C. § 2301. These principles safeguard against political interference by mandating fair and competitive hiring based on ability and qualifications. The proposed changes would subvert this established framework, allowing increased partisanship in civil service roles and weakening the public trust in government decision-making, particularly in scientific and technical domains.

For these reasons, I urge OPM to withdraw the proposed rule and reaffirm the federal government’s current commitment to nonpartisan, merit-based hiring practices that protect the integrity of civil service and preserve the objectivity essential to scientific research administration.

title: Comment from Benjamin Rainey
comment:
I strongly oppose the implementation or revival of the “Schedule F” classification for federal employees. This proposal threatens the merit-based civil service system that has underpinned a professional, nonpartisan federal workforce for over a century.

First and foremost, the creation of Schedule F directly undermines the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883, which was enacted to combat the spoils system and establish a merit-based hiring process for federal employees. By allowing a broad swath of career civil servants—particularly those involved in policy-making or analysis—to be reclassified and potentially terminated without cause, Schedule F opens the door to politically motivated hiring and firing. This is antithetical to the principle of an apolitical civil service enshrined in 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8), which mandates that federal employment decisions be based on merit and free from political influence.

Moreover, the vague and sweeping criteria for inclusion in Schedule F violate the due process protections guaranteed by 5 U.S.C. § 7513, which requires cause and procedural safeguards for the removal of career federal employees. Stripping thousands of workers of these protections not only weakens accountability but also risks chilling expert advice and dissent within agencies—undermining the very effectiveness of government operations.

The Office of Personnel Management (OPM) is also bound by 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq. to support the merit system principles. Implementing Schedule F contradicts this statutory mission and places undue political pressure on career professionals, compromising the integrity and continuity of federal programs across administrations.

In conclusion, the Schedule F proposal poses a grave threat to the foundational principles of good governance, civil service independence, and the rule of law. I urge the administration and OPM to reject any regulatory framework that seeks to implement or revive this dangerous classification.

title: Comment from Elizabeth Brand

Third, there is a reason that political appointees and civil servants are differentiated between in status. This proposed rule would essentially transform all federal employees to political appointees, subject to be fired at will by the executive. title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
I strongly oppose the implementation or revival of the “Schedule F” classification for federal employees. This proposal threatens the merit-based civil service system that has underpinned a professional, nonpartisan federal workforce for over a century.

First and foremost, the creation of Schedule F directly undermines the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883, which was enacted to combat the spoils system and establish a merit-based hiring process for federal employees. By allowing a broad swath of career civil servants—particularly those involved in policy-making or analysis—to be reclassified and potentially terminated without cause, Schedule F opens the door to politically motivated hiring and firing. This is antithetical to the principle of an apolitical civil service enshrined in 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8), which mandates that federal employment decisions be based on merit and free from political influence.

Moreover, the vague and sweeping criteria for inclusion in Schedule F violate the due process protections guaranteed by 5 U.S.C. § 7513, which requires cause and procedural safeguards for the removal of career federal employees. Stripping thousands of workers of these protections not only weakens accountability but also risks chilling expert advice and dissent within agencies—undermining the very effectiveness of government operations.

The Office of Personnel Management (OPM) is also bound by 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq. to support the merit system principles. Implementing Schedule F contradicts this statutory mission and places undue political pressure on career professionals, compromising the integrity and continuity of federal programs across administrations.

In conclusion, the Schedule F proposal poses a grave threat to the foundational principles of good governance, civil service independence, and the rule of law. I urge the administration and OPM to reject any regulatory framework that seeks to implement or revive this dangerous classification.

title: Comment from Fiona Kearns
comment: I am a postdoctoral scholar working in a laboratory located within one of the top research universities in the world. Decreasing protections for civil servants, as would be the case if Schedule F initiative were enacted would be greatly detrimental to the continuance of excellent and rigorous science, for which the United States is known worldwide. Furthermore, enacting of a Schedule F initiative could be considered a dramatic step in the direction of fascism and at the very least considered a demonstration of government overreach. I urge all government officials to fight against the Schedule F initiative and preserve what level of government efficiency we have remaining.

title: Comment from Heidi Henninger
comment:
I'm writing to vehemently oppose the return to the “Schedule F” classification for non-political federal employees. This proposal threatens the merit-based civil service system that has underpinned the nonpartisan federal workforce for over a century and threatens to reclassify many positions that should not be held by political appointees.

Looking to our present laws, the proposed Schedule F directly would undermine the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883, which was enacted to combat the spoils system and establish a merit-based hiring process for federal employees. By allowing a broad swath of career civil servants—particularly those involved in policy-making or analysis—to be reclassified and potentially terminated without cause, Schedule F opens the door to politically motivated hiring and firing. This is antithetical to the principle of an apolitical civil service enshrined in 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8) and violates the due process protections guaranteed by 5 U.S.C. § 7513, which requires cause for the removal of career federal employees. Stripping thousands of workers of these protections not only weakens accountability but also risks chilling expert advice and dissent within agencies—undermining the very effectiveness of government operations.

The Office of Personnel Management (OPM) is also bound by 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq. to support the merit system principles. Implementing Schedule F contradicts this statutory mission and places undue political pressure on career professionals, compromising the integrity and continuity of federal programs across administrations.

This proposal is completely counter to the regulations cited above, good governance and civil service independence. I oppose this proposed rule and urge the Administration to refrain from moving forward with reclassifications.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
I write to respectfully request that the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) extend the public comment period for the above-referenced proposed rule for an additional 30 days, for a total of at least 60 days.

The proposed rule seeks to fundamentally restructure the accountability framework for career civil servants in policy-influencing roles by creating a new “Schedule Policy/Career” in the excepted service. The rule would remove these positions from the procedural protections of 5 U.S.C. chapters 43 and 75, thereby significantly affecting the due process rights of thousands of federal employees. Given the substantial implications of these changes—for employee rights, agency operations, and the merit-based foundations of the civil service—it is critical that stakeholders have adequate time to analyze the proposal and submit meaningful comments.

Executive Order 12866 (Regulatory Planning and Review) requires that significant regulatory actions allow “no less than 60 days” for public comment in most cases. Section 6(a)(1) of the Executive Order provides:

“Each agency shall provide the public with meaningful participation in the regulatory process. In most cases, this means a comment period of not less than 60 days.”

The proposed rule at issue has been classified as a significant regulatory action. It directly implements Executive Order 14171, which redefines the legal standards governing federal civil service positions, with sweeping consequences for personnel policy. The legal, constitutional, and operational complexities surrounding these changes necessitate a longer period for public input to ensure that all viewpoints—including those of affected federal employees, good government groups, legal scholars, and the general public—can be thoroughly considered.

In light of the magnitude of the proposed changes and in keeping with the intent of Executive Order 12866, we urge OPM to extend the public comment deadline from May 23, 2025, to at least June 22, 2025.

Thank you for your consideration of this request and for your commitment to transparent and inclusive rulemaking.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
While the intention behind the OPM's proposed rule to increase accountability for career employees may appear beneficial at first glance, there are significant concerns that must be addressed regarding the implications of moving certain positions to Schedule Policy/Career and making them at-will.
     First and foremost, classifying policy-influencing positions as at-will raises questions about the potential erosion of job security and due process for employees in critical roles. The absence of adverse action procedures or appeals creates an environment ripe for potential abuse and arbitrary dismissals. Employees may now live in fear of being removed not solely for misconduct or poor performance but also for ideological differences or merely crossing paths with supervisory agendas. This lack of job security can lead to a stifling atmosphere that discourages innovation, dissent, and the voice of experienced professionals who need a platform to provide critical insights and opinions that could enhance policy decisions.
     It's also crucial to consider the implications of what defines "misconduct" or "poor performance." The subjective nature of these terms can lead to inconsistencies in how different supervisors may apply them. Without standardized criteria and robust oversight, the potential for discrimination, favoritism, or political bias in the termination process increases significantly. The very essence of fairness in employment might be compromised, undermining trust in the institution as a whole.
     Finally, insisting that policy-influencing positions remain nonpartisan while simultaneously creating a landscape that can lead to political overreach is contradictory. Employees in these roles must feel secure enough to perform their duties independently, without the threat of political reprisal. The proposed rule may exacerbate concerns about politicization within the federal workforce, as employees could become susceptible to pressures that influence their work, compromising the integrity of the decisions made by government agencies.
     I am choosing to leave this comment anonymously in fear of retaliation.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
I strongly oppose any effort to implement Schedule F, a proposed federal employment classification that threatens the integrity, impartiality, and effectiveness of the U.S. civil service.

Schedule F, as introduced by the current administration would allow broad reclassification of federal employees involved in "policy-determining, policymaking, or policy-advocating" roles, stripping them of their due process and merit-based civil service protections. This reclassification would open the door to mass politicization of the civil service, undermining a foundational principle of American democracy: that government professionals serve the public interest—not the political interest of any one administration.

Erosion of Merit-Based Employment

The core of the U.S. civil service system is its reliance on merit-based hiring and retention. By creating a new class of federal employees exempt from competitive hiring and procedural protections, Schedule F undermines this foundation. It risks turning experienced, apolitical experts into political appointees subject to loyalty tests and partisan whims. In sum, implementing Schedule F would damage the effectiveness, independence, and credibility of the federal workforce. It opens the door to patronage, diminishes the morale of public servants, and threatens the democratic principle of nonpartisan governance. title: Comment from Nicholas Steinmetz
comment:
I am commenting on Docket ID: OPM-2025-0004, RIN 3206-AO80 from the Office of Personnel Management, and specifically commenting on the text in Supplementary Information Section I.B.2 (url: https://www.federalregister.gov/d/2025-06904/p-158). I am an Assistant Professor at the University of Washington School of Medicine, and run a neuroscience lab funded partly by funds from the NIH. 

I concur with the objectives of the proposed rule, namely the goal of holding employees accountable for poor performance and making it easier to remove such poorly-performing employees from their positions. The challenges imposed by chapter 75 and chapter 43 are identified as key limits on having appropriate accountability. However, the text as given identifies that federal employees involved in grant-making should be classified as political appointees rather than career civil servants. This shift seems to be proposed only as an expedient method of making more employees easily removable, but does not directly address the concerns with the protections written into chapters 75 and 43. If the problem is that chapters 75 and 43 specify protections that are too onerous to meet and which are actively harming governmental efficacy, then OPM should seek to change those chapters. Changing the categorization of different positions to make them more easily removable is a solution with unintended and undesirable side effects, specifically, it removes the independence of scientists to pursue truth, free from the policy objectives of the administration. One could easily imagine abuse of this change if, for instance, an administration were to come to power with the goal of preventing research on links between vaccines and autism, and were to appoint a person into a grantmaking position who could block all such research. This would significantly restrict the freedom of scientists to pursue such links if they desired to do so.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
I submit this comment in strong opposition to the proposed rule to establish “Schedule Policy/Career” in the excepted service, as published in the Federal Register on April 23, 2025 (90 FR 17182).

The proposed rule constitutes a sweeping reclassification of career civil servants in “policy-influencing” positions into a new category of at-will employees, stripped of long-standing procedural protections under chapters 43 and 75 of Title 5. This raises profound legal, constitutional, and operational concerns.

1. Due Process and Legal Precedent
The rule undermines procedural due process guarantees recognized by the U.S. Supreme Court in Arnett v. Kennedy and its progeny. These protections were codified by Congress in the Civil Service Reform Act of 1978 to prevent arbitrary removals and ensure civil servants are not penalized for political or personal reasons. By eliminating appeal rights and adverse action procedures for employees with property interests in their jobs, the rule exposes the government to constitutional challenge.

2. Contravention of Congressional Intent
Congress has repeatedly affirmed the importance of a professional, merit-based civil service. By shifting employees into an at-will status without legislative input, the proposed rule improperly sidelines the statutory framework Congress enacted to protect career employees and maintain government neutrality.

3. Erosion of Merit System Principles
The merit system exists to protect both employees and the public from politicization of the civil service. Removing adverse action protections for “policy-influencing” employees risks creating a chilling effect on internal dissent and encourages self-censorship, undermining the very accountability the rule purports to enhance.

4. Insufficient Justification for Reversal
The rule seeks to overturn the April 2024 final rule with minimal justification. The rationale offered—largely consisting of political preference and unquantified surveys—is insufficient under the Administrative Procedure Act. A mere change in presidential administration does not justify abandonment of established policy without substantial evidence.

5. Unlawful Curtailment of Public Participation
Despite the substantial nature of the rule, OPM has allowed only 30 days for public comment, contravening the 60-day minimum generally required under Executive Order 12866. The rule’s complexity and implications necessitate a full and fair opportunity for public input.

For all of the above reasons, I urge OPM to withdraw this proposed rule in its entirety. If not withdrawn, at a minimum, the comment period must be extended to 60 days to allow stakeholders to fully analyze and respond to the significant legal and policy issues raised.

This change should not be implemented unless the goal is to degrade the US's technological standing in the world and cede our current strategic advantages to China.

title: Comment from Riley Hannan
comment:
RE: OPM–2025–0004

I speak from the specific background of HHS-funded not-for-profit biomedical research, but I believe my sentiments likely apply to all grant-funded work administered by any executive agency. 

On its face, with the most charitable interpretation, changing apolitical appointments to political appointments using schedule F will cause huge instability and turnover in the governmental apparatus with each new administration. This will stymie any efforts by the federal government to execute or maintain projects with time horizons beyond 4 years, effectively crippling the countless valuable missions and services which are currently provided to the American people. I do not believe this is in the best interests of the American people, nor the executive branch itself, should it desire to continue functioning at a baseline level. 

As an editorial - within the larger context of Vought's (current head of OPM) public comments and the goals outlined in Project 2025, the reclassification of feds as political appointees using Schedule F is *EXPLICITLY* outlined as a tool to eliminate the ability of the various executive agencies and departments to execute their mission, in service of an unsupported claim that "States are better resource managers than the federal government because they must live with the results." Vought / this administration knows that these roles currently filled by the federal government will, of course, not be recapitulated by the states, and block grants disbursed by the federal government (if any) will not be spent in service of the American public, instead going to the profits of contractors and subcontractors. The privatization and federalism/balkanization of the executive branch should not be allowed, will cause untold harm to Americans, likely disproportionately affect the most vulnerable, and only serve to enrich corporate donors.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
Schedule F poses a serious threat to the economy by destabilizing the federal government’s ability to efficiently implement and regulate policies that are vital to economic growth, stability, and innovation. Federal agencies play a critical role in ensuring a functioning economy, from enforcing financial regulations and overseeing industries to implementing trade policies and managing public infrastructure. When these roles are politicized, it undermines the effectiveness and consistency of economic governance.

First, Schedule F allows for the dismissal of career civil servants with deep expertise in areas like financial regulation, environmental policy, and trade. Replacing them with politically motivated appointees risks weakening the quality of decision-making. Expert, nonpartisan staff are essential for navigating complex economic issues, from responding to financial crises to ensuring fair competition and protecting consumer interests. If these professionals are replaced based on loyalty rather than skill, the resulting decisions are more likely to be shortsighted, politically motivated, or poorly informed—decisions that could have a long-term negative impact on the economy.

Second, Schedule F threatens continuity in policymaking. Economic policies often take years to fully develop and implement. Civil servants are the institutional memory of the government—ensuring that policies are carried out over time and are adjusted based on facts, data, and experience. A highly politicized civil service leads to constant turnover, creating policy instability that undermines investor confidence, discourages long-term planning, and makes it more difficult for businesses to navigate regulations.

Moreover, the disruption caused by politicizing key positions could hinder effective responses to economic challenges, such as managing a recession, addressing unemployment, or promoting sustainable economic growth. A government that operates in a state of flux—where staff are replaced based on political loyalty—will struggle to maintain the level of expertise and strategic foresight necessary to address these complex issues.

In sum, Schedule F jeopardizes the stability, expertise, and continuity of federal economic governance, potentially leading to regulatory inefficiencies, poor decision-making, and uncertainty in the market. The ultimate result is a weaker economy, with consequences that affect businesses, workers, and the public at large.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
I oppose this proposed rule, also known as Schedule F as it threatens the merit-based civil service system that has underpinned a professional, nonpartisan federal workforce for over a century.
First and foremost, the creation of Schedule F directly undermines the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883, which was enacted to combat the spoils system and establish a merit-based hiring process for federal employees. By allowing a broad swath of career civil servants-particularly those involved in policy-making or analysis-to be reclassified and potentially terminated without cause, Schedule F opens the door to politically motivated hiring and firing. This is antithetical to the principle of an apolitical civil service enshrined in 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b) (8), which mandates that federal employment decisions be based on merit and free from political influence.
Moreover, the vague and sweeping criteria for inclusion in Schedule F violate the due process protections guaranteed by 5 U.S.C. § 7513, which requires cause and procedural safeguards for the removal of career federal employees. Stripping thousands of workers of these protections not only weakens accountability but also risks chilling expert advice and dissent within agencies-undermining the very effectiveness of government operations.
The Office of Personnel Management (OPM) is also bound by 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq. to support the merit system principles. Implementing Schedule F contradicts this statutory mission and places undue political pressure on career professionals, compromising the integrity and continuity of federal programs across administrations.
In conclusion, the Schedule F proposal poses a grave threat to the foundational principles of good governance, civil service independence, and the rule of law. I urge the administration and OPM to reject any regulatory framework that seeks to implement or revive this dangerous classification.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
The U.S. civil service system was established with the Pendleton Act of 1883 in response to the corruption and inefficiency of the spoils system, where government jobs were awarded based on political loyalty rather than competence. The merit system is designed to ensure that public servants are hired and retained based on qualifications and performance, not political affiliation. Schedule F undermines this foundation by permitting political appointees to reclassify career employees, potentially leading to mass dismissals based on ideology or perceived disloyalty rather than job performance. 

Reintroducing Schedule F could result in the loss of thousands of experienced career officials who possess institutional knowledge critical to the functioning of government. These professionals play a key role in maintaining continuity across administrations, developing evidence-based policy, and upholding legal and ethical standards. Their replacement with politically loyal personnel risks creating an unstable, inconsistent, and partisan bureaucracy, undermining the government’s long-term effectiveness.

Schedule F promotes politicization by allowing administrations to purge civil servants and replace them with loyalists. This approach echoes the 19th-century spoils system, which contributed to rampant corruption and inefficiency. Politicization compromises the integrity of public administration and blurs the distinction between neutral competence and partisan agenda, ultimately damaging public trust in government institutions.

Civil servants are bound by codes of conduct and ethics that are designed to ensure impartial service to the public, not to political interests. Weakening their job protections through mechanisms like Schedule F increases pressure to conform to political demands, even when those demands conflict with established law or best practices. This dynamic opens the door to misuse of government for partisan gain and reduces accountability. 

Reinstituting Schedule F would mark a regression toward a spoils system that prioritizes political loyalty over professional competence. Such a shift threatens the nonpartisan foundation of the federal civil service, jeopardizes institutional integrity, and erodes public trust in government. The merit-based civil service system, while not without its flaws, remains essential to democratic governance, stability, and accountability.

It’s is ludicrous to implement a spoils system just so Russel Vought can feel like a big powerful man because his mother never loved him and his friends can’t stand him.

comment:
I strongly oppose the implementation or revival of the "Schedule F" classification for federal employees. This proposal threatens the merit-based civil service system that has underpinned a professional, nonpartisan federal workforce for over a century.

If passed, this regulation would return us to a spoils system, in violation of the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883. This act was passed to rid us of the corruption rampant in the executive branch of government during the Gilded Age and was a direct response to the assassination of President Garfield, who was shot by a disappointed donor promised an ambassadorship. Stripping thousands of employees of their protections would have a chilling effect on dissent with the agencies, due to fear of reprisal.

Schedule F will likely be interpreted very broadly, impacting employees whose position has no impact on policy just because one job in their career series may have policy influence. Filling the executive branch with only those loyal to the current government (vice the constitution) has proven to lead only to corruption and government waste, fraud, and abuse as in the post Civil War era United States of America. Repeating these mistakes will only be to the United States' detriment.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
As an engaged citizen, I strongly urge OPM to withdraw the proposed Schedule F rule. Its enactment would dismantle long-standing civil service protections, introduce unconstitutional practices, and undermine the core principles of a merit-based, nonpartisan federal workforce.

I. SUMMARY OF POSITION
I respectfully oppose the proposed “Schedule F” classification (5 CFR Parts 210, 212, 213, 302, 432, 451, and 752). By broadly stripping procedural and merit-based protections from thousands of policy-influencing career employees, the rule:
    A. Undermines the competitive, nonpartisan civil service;
    B. Exposes employees to at-will removal without notice or hearing;
    C. Threatens institutional memory, whistleblower reporting, and ethical governance.

II. KEY LEGAL & POLICY CONCERNS
1. Civil Service Reform Act of 1978 (CSRA)
The CSRA’s merit-system principles and removal protections cannot be bypassed by a catch-all Schedule F designation and remain eligible only for narrowly defined “confidential or policy-determining” roles.

2. Lloyd–La Follette Act of 1912
Mandates advance notice and written findings before removal. Schedule F would eliminate these statutory safeguards.

3. Fifth Amendment Due Process
Cleveland Bd. of Educ. v. Loudermill confirms a property interest in federal employment; at-will termination without a hearing violates due process.

4. Administrative Procedure Act (APA)
The NPRM provides insufficient analysis of costs, benefits, or less-drastic alternatives, and appears to pre-decide key issues without fully addressing public comments.

5. Pendleton Civil Service Act of 1883
Established merit hiring and protection from patronage; Schedule F risks reintroducing politically motivated dismissals.

6. Whistleblower Protections
By removing tenure safeguards, Schedule F would chill reporting of fraud, waste, and abuse, undermining Congress’s express whistleblower statutes.

7. Major Questions Doctrine
A rule of such sweeping scope requires clear congressional authorization. No explicit statute grants OPM authority to reclassify tens of thousands of careers positions into an at-will service.

III. ALTERNATIVE RECOMMENDATIONS
    A. Rescind the NPRM in favor of targeted reforms that preserve due-process rights.
    B. Limit any new excepted service category to genuinely policy-confidential positions with clear statutory language.
    C. Conduct a GAO cost-benefit and risk analysis, including impacts on recruitment, retention, and whistleblower referrals.

IV. CLARIFYING QUESTIONS
1. Which position descriptions, occupational series, and pay grades are subject to Schedule F reclassification, and what objective criteria will guide those determinations?
2. Under the proposed rule, who—agency HR, OPM, or the White House—has final authority to designate a position as Schedule F, and what documentation must accompany each action?
3. Precisely how will the rule modify existing removal procedures, appeals rights, and grievance mechanisms now found in 5 U.S.C. § 7513 and 5 C.F.R. Part 752?
4. What is the intended timeline for agency review, designation notices to incumbents, and full implementation across all executive departments?
5. On what statutory bases does OPM rely to override or amend CSRA provisions, and how does the rule interact with statutes such as the Lloyd–La Follette and Pendleton Acts?
6. How will OPM address APA requirements—particularly the need for a reasoned explanation of alternatives considered and a detailed response to significant public comments?
7.  What internal or external oversight (e.g., OIG, GAO, Inspector General) will monitor Schedule F designations to prevent abuse or politicization?
8.  How will agencies measure and report on the anticipated benefits, costs, and impacts on workforce morale and institutional knowledge?
9. What training and guidance will be provided to supervisors and HR practitioners to ensure consistent, lawful application of Schedule F criteria?
10. How will Schedule F status affect existing whistleblower channels and protections under 5 U.S.C. § 2302(b)(8), and what recourse will employees have if they believe retaliatory removal occurred?

title: Comment from Lewis Larels
comment:
Section E's rationale is untenable due to its failure to meet baseline standards for information quality and regulatory analysis, lacking objective evidence to support its cost-benefit claims. Moreover, the proposal constitutes an executive overreach into Congress's core legislative function of structuring the federal civil service and defining statutory rights. These analytical and constitutional deficiencies compel the proposal's rejection.

* Non-Compliance with Information Quality & Regulatory Analysis Standards: OPM’s dismissal of established reliance interests rests on a deficient analytical foundation, failing standards mandated by the Information Quality Act (Pub. L. 106-554, § 515) and Executive Orders on regulatory review (e.g., E.O. 12866/13563). These standards require objectivity, utility, integrity, and analysis based on the best reasonably obtainable scientific, technical, economic, and other information. Section E offers conclusory statements that reliance interests are "misplaced" or "outweighed" by vaguely defined harms ("poor performance," "partisanship") without presenting credible, objective data demonstrating the scope of these harms specifically within the target population or proving they are unaddressable through existing means. Crucially, it lacks a rigorous, evidence-based assessment of the substantial costs associated with removing procedural safeguards—including loss of specialized expertise, diminished recruitment appeal for critical roles, institutional instability, and the erosion of objective analysis within agencies. This failure to conduct a balanced, data-driven cost-benefit analysis renders the justification inadequate under established requirements for reasoned agency decision-making.

 * Encroachment upon Congress's Legislative Power (Article I): The proposal fundamentally alters the employment status and rights of a significant segment of the federal workforce established under laws enacted by Congress. Article I grants Congress the power to structure the government, including establishing offices and regulating the conditions of federal employment, particularly for non-principal officers (Cf. Myers v. United States, 272 U.S. 52 (1926); Humphrey's Executor v. United States, 295 U.S. 602 (1935)). Through the Civil Service Reform Act (CSRA), Congress meticulously designed the current system, including specifying which career employees receive Chapter 75 procedural protections (5 U.S.C. § 7511). OPM's creation of "Schedule Policy/Career" via regulation, effectively exempting incumbents from these statutory protections based on functional descriptions OPM devises, constitutes an exercise of power akin to legislative amendment. It oversteps OPM's executive authority to implement the law and usurps Congress's constitutional prerogative to make the law governing the fundamental structure and rights within the civil service.

 * Disregard for Procedural Protections as Congressional Structural Choice: The adverse action procedures OPM seeks to eliminate are not merely individual employee benefits; they represent a deliberate structural choice by Congress designed to ensure a measure of independence, expertise, and continuity within the executive branch, balancing presidential oversight with the need for a stable, law-governed administration. OPM’s rationale treats these protections as disposable inconveniences rather than integral parts of Congress's legislative design for how the executive branch should function—a design OPM lacks the authority to unilaterally override through regulation based on shifting policy preferences.

 * Failure to Justify Necessity Over Less Intrusive Means: Sound regulatory principles require agencies justify rules as necessary and consider less burdensome alternatives. OPM has not adequately demonstrated why the existing tools under Chapters 43 and 75—statutory mechanisms specifically designed by Congress to address performance and conduct—are insufficient, nor why less drastic alternatives (e.g., targeted performance improvement plans, enhanced suitability determinations for specific roles within the current framework) could not achieve its stated objectives without dismantling core statutory protections. This failure undercuts the necessity of the proposed radical change.

title: Comment from Silence Dogood
comment:
Preamble
As an engaged citizen with direct experience in rule-making, I have no predisposed stance on the Schedule F proposal. To evaluate its legality, scope, and practical effects, I respectfully request detailed information on the rule’s design, implementation, and oversight. The following questions are intended to elicit clear, specific explanations that will inform a thorough legal analysis.

Clarifying Questions
1.	Scope of “Policy-Influencing”:
How exactly is “policy-influencing” defined, and what job duties or decision-making thresholds determine inclusion in Schedule F?
2.	Interaction with Existing Classification Systems:
How will Schedule F interact with the competitive service, excepted service, and Senior Executive Service classifications under current OPM regulations?
3.	Impact on Competitive Hiring and Promotion:
Will reclassified roles remain open to public competition and merit-based promotion, or will Schedule F positions be filled by non-competitive appointment?
4.	Collective Bargaining and Union Rights:
What effect will Schedule F have on collective bargaining agreements, union representation, and grievance procedures for affected employees?
5.	Interagency Mobility and Detail Assignments:
How will Schedule F status affect an employee’s ability to accept temporary detail assignments, reassignments, or interagency transfers?
6.	Metrics and Appeals for Reclassification:
What quantifiable criteria and procedural deadlines govern an incumbent’s challenge to a Schedule F reclassification decision?
7.	Data Privacy and Security Obligations:
How will agency responsibilities under the Privacy Act and FISMA apply to Schedule F roles—particularly those handling sensitive or classified information?
8.	Equal Employment Opportunity (EEO) Considerations:
What analyses will OPM or agencies perform to ensure that Schedule F designations do not disproportionately impact protected classes or hinder EEO program goals?
9.	Transition Provisions for Incumbents vs. New Hires:
Will current employees automatically convert to Schedule F status, and what rights or timelines will be afforded to incumbents versus future appointees?
10.	Revocation and Sunset Mechanisms:
What procedures and criteria will govern the revocation of Schedule F status from a position, and is there a built-in sunset or periodic review requirement?

Summary
Obtaining precise answers to these questions is essential to assess whether Schedule F’s reclassification framework aligns with statutory mandates, protects employee rights, and maintains government effectiveness. Clear guidance on each point will enable a rigorous evaluation of the rule’s legal and operational viability.

title: Comment from Lewis Larels
comment:
Section E's rationale is untenable due to its failure to meet baseline standards for information quality and regulatory analysis, lacking objective evidence to support its cost-benefit claims. Moreover, the proposal constitutes an executive overreach into Congress's core legislative function of structuring the federal civil service and defining statutory rights. These analytical and constitutional deficiencies compel the proposal's rejection.

* Non-Compliance with Information Quality & Regulatory Analysis Standards: OPM’s dismissal of established reliance interests rests on a deficient analytical foundation, failing standards mandated by the Information Quality Act (Pub. L. 106-554, § 515) and Executive Orders on regulatory review (e.g., E.O. 12866/13563). These standards require objectivity, utility, integrity, and analysis based on the best reasonably obtainable scientific, technical, economic, and other information. Section E offers conclusory statements that reliance interests are "misplaced" or "outweighed" by vaguely defined harms ("poor performance," "partisanship") without presenting credible, objective data demonstrating the scope of these harms specifically within the target population or proving they are unaddressable through existing means. Crucially, it lacks a rigorous, evidence-based assessment of the substantial costs associated with removing procedural safeguards—including loss of specialized expertise, diminished recruitment appeal for critical roles, institutional instability, and the erosion of objective analysis within agencies. This failure to conduct a balanced, data-driven cost-benefit analysis renders the justification inadequate under established requirements for reasoned agency decision-making.

 * Encroachment upon Congress's Legislative Power (Article I): The proposal fundamentally alters the employment status and rights of a significant segment of the federal workforce established under laws enacted by Congress. Article I grants Congress the power to structure the government, including establishing offices and regulating the conditions of federal employment, particularly for non-principal officers (Cf. Myers v. United States, 272 U.S. 52 (1926); Humphrey's Executor v. United States, 295 U.S. 602 (1935)). Through the Civil Service Reform Act (CSRA), Congress meticulously designed the current system, including specifying which career employees receive Chapter 75 procedural protections (5 U.S.C. § 7511). OPM's creation of "Schedule Policy/Career" via regulation, effectively exempting incumbents from these statutory protections based on functional descriptions OPM devises, constitutes an exercise of power akin to legislative amendment. It oversteps OPM's executive authority to implement the law and usurps Congress's constitutional prerogative to make the law governing the fundamental structure and rights within the civil service.

 * Disregard for Procedural Protections as Congressional Structural Choice: The adverse action procedures OPM seeks to eliminate are not merely individual employee benefits; they represent a deliberate structural choice by Congress designed to ensure a measure of independence, expertise, and continuity within the executive branch, balancing presidential oversight with the need for a stable, law-governed administration. OPM’s rationale treats these protections as disposable inconveniences rather than integral parts of Congress's legislative design for how the executive branch should function—a design OPM lacks the authority to unilaterally override through regulation based on shifting policy preferences.

 * Failure to Justify Necessity Over Less Intrusive Means: Sound regulatory principles require agencies justify rules as necessary and consider less burdensome alternatives. OPM has not adequately demonstrated why the existing tools under Chapters 43 and 75—statutory mechanisms specifically designed by Congress to address performance and conduct—are insufficient, nor why less drastic alternatives (e.g., targeted performance improvement plans, enhanced suitability determinations for specific roles within the current framework) could not achieve its stated objectives without dismantling core statutory protections. This failure undercuts the necessity of the proposed radical change.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
I strongly oppose the implementation or revival of the "Schedule F" classification for federal employees. This proposal threatens the merit-based civil service system that has underpinned a professional, nonpartisan federal workforce for over a century.

If passed, this regulation would return us to a spoils system, in violation of the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883. This act was passed to rid us of the corruption rampant in the executive branch of government during the Gilded Age and was a direct response to the assassination of President Garfield, who was shot by a disappointed donor promised an ambassadorship. The Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act ensured that the hiring and promotion in the executive branch of the government is based on merit; it also ensures stability in our federal government as hirings are non-partisan and not based on loyalty or patronage to any specific politician. 

Additionally, the vague and sweeping criteria for inclusion in Schedule F violates the due process protections guaranteed by 5 U.S.C. 7513, which requires cause and procedural safeguards for the removal of career federal employees. Stripping thousands of employees of their protections would have a chilling effect on dissent with the agencies, due to fear of reprisal.

Schedule F will likely be interpreted very broadly, impacting employees whose position has no impact on policy just because one job in their career series may have policy influence. Filling the executive branch with only those loyal to the current government (vice the constitution) has proven to lead only to corruption and government waste, fraud, and abuse as in the post Civil War era United States of America. Repeating these mistakes will only be to the United States' detriment.

title: Comment from R Sandler
comment:
I am against schedule F.

The proposed Schedule Policy/Career rule, which would reclassify certain federal employees into "at-will" positions exempt from competitive service protections, contravenes longstanding civil service laws, violates congressional intent, and risks judicial invalidation. Below is a substantive legal critique:

Statutory Protections Under the Civil Service Reform Act (CSRA) and Title 5
The Civil Service Reform Act of 1978 (CSRA) (Pub. L. 95-454) established a merit-based system for federal employment, codified in Title 5 of the U.S. Code. Key provisions include:

5 U.S.C. § 2301 – Mandates that federal personnel decisions be based on merit and free from political coercion.

5 U.S.C. § 3301 – Grants the President authority to prescribe regulations for the competitive service but does not permit blanket removal of due process rights.

5 U.S.C. § 7513 – Requires that career employees in the competitive service may only be removed for cause and after procedural protections (notice, right to respond, appeal rights).

Legal Conflict: Schedule F attempts to circumvent these statutory due process protections by reclassifying employees into an excepted service category (5 C.F.R. Part 212), effectively stripping them of § 7513 rights without congressional authorization.

2. Violation of Congressional Intent
Congress has repeatedly reinforced civil service protections, including:

The Pendleton Act (1883) – Ended the spoils system by requiring merit-based hiring.

The Lloyd-La Follette Act (5 U.S.C. § 7211) – Protects federal employees’ rights to petition Congress and speak out without retaliation.

The Whistleblower Protection Act (5 U.S.C. § 2302(b)(8)) – Shields employees who disclose wrongdoing.

Judicial Precedent: Courts have ruled that the executive branch cannot unilaterally override statutory employment protections. In NTEU v. Reagan (1985), the courts upheld that the President’s removal authority is constrained by civil service laws. Similarly, in Elgin v. Dep’t of the Treasury* (2012), the Supreme Court affirmed that federal employees have statutory appeal rights under the CSRA.

3. Separation of Powers Concerns
The Constitution vests Congress with authority over federal employment (Article I, § 8; Article II, § 2). While the President has removal power (Myers v. U.S., 1926), it is not absolute. In Humphrey’s Executor v. U.S. (1935), the Court ruled that Congress can impose restrictions on the removal of certain officials to ensure independence.

Legal Risk: Schedule F’s broad reclassification of policy-related roles likely exceeds OPM’s regulatory authority under 5 U.S.C. § 3302, which requires that exceptions to competitive service rules be "necessary" and "conditions of good administration." Courts may strike it down as arbitrary and capricious under Motor Vehicle Mfrs. Ass’n v. State Farm (1983).

4. Due Process and First Amendment Implications

Fifth Amendment Due Process: Federal employees with a property interest in their jobs (Cleveland Bd. of Educ. v. Loudermill, 1985) cannot be deprived of employment without due process. Schedule F eliminates these protections without justification.

First Amendment Retaliation: If employees are fired for political reasons, this could violate Branti v. Finkel (1980), which bars patronage dismissals unless party affiliation is a legitimate job requirement.

Administrative Procedure Act (APA) Violations
OPM’s rulemaking must comply with the APA (5 U.S.C. §§ 551-559). If Schedule F is implemented without sufficient justification or public input, it could be challenged as:

Arbitrary and capricious (State Farm, 1983);

In excess of statutory authority (Chevron U.S.A. v. NRDC, 1984).

Conclusion: Schedule F Is Legally Unsound
The proposed rule disregards Title 5 protections, congressional intent, and judicial precedent safeguarding merit-based civil service. If implemented, it invites litigation under the CSRA, APA, and Constitutional doctrines, with a high likelihood of being struck down. Instead of dismantling due process rights, OPM should focus on strengthening workforce accountability within existing framework

title: Comment from Andi Gaston
comment:
I strongly oppose the implementation or revival of the “Schedule F” classification for federal employees. This proposal represents a profound threat to the merit-based civil service system that has sustained a professional, nonpartisan federal workforce for over a century.


At its core, Schedule F would dismantle key protections established by the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883, which replaced the spoils system with merit-based hiring. Reclassifying a broad segment of career civil servants—especially those involved in policy-making and analysis—would allow for termination without cause, effectively turning these roles into political appointments. This invites politicized hiring and firing practices that directly contradict the principles of an apolitical civil service outlined in 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8).


Equally troubling, the sweeping and ambiguous criteria for Schedule F inclusion undermine due process protections guaranteed by 5 U.S.C. § 7513, eroding safeguards designed to prevent arbitrary dismissals. Removing these protections not only jeopardizes the impartiality of expert advisors but creates a chilling effect that discourages dissent and candor—vital components of effective governance.


Moreover, such instability would result in a revolving door of employment, where seasoned professionals are replaced en masse with each political shift. This turnover would severely disrupt the continuity of government operations and the consistent delivery of services to the public. Federal agencies rely on institutional knowledge and long-term experience to implement programs effectively—resources that cannot be replaced overnight.


The Office of Personnel Management, under 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq., is tasked with upholding merit system principles. Schedule F runs counter to this mission and would inject undue political pressure into the daily work of civil servants, threatening the long-term integrity of federal programs that Americans depend on.


In conclusion, the Schedule F proposal undermines good governance, civil service independence, and the stability essential for sustained public service delivery. I urge the administration and OPM to reject any framework that would implement or revive this harmful classification.

Removing these protections not only jeopardizes the impartiality of expert advisors but creates a chilling effect that discourages dissent and candor—vital components of effective governance.


Moreover, such instability would result in a revolving door of employment, where seasoned professionals are replaced en masse with each political shift. This turnover would severely disrupt the continuity of government operations and the consistent delivery of services to the public. Federal agencies rely on institutional knowledge and long-term experience to implement programs effectively—resources that cannot be replaced overnight.


The Office of Personnel Management, under 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq., is tasked with upholding merit system principles. Schedule F runs counter to this mission and would inject undue political pressure into the daily work of civil servants, threatening the long-term integrity of federal programs that Americans depend on.

title: Comment from John Lamm
comment:
Based on my experience with both government employment and supervision of government employees, I believe that rules for career civil service can at times restrict the ability to remove poor performers. However, removing adverse action proceedings and appeal rights would only increase the likelihood of workplace harassment, intimidation, retaliation, and other forms of misconduct. Allowing supervisors to remove employees without documenting misconduct or poor performance would reduce accountability instead of increasing it. The rule as currently written delinks performance from decision-making about whether an employee should continue to work at an agency--which is the opposite of the stated intent of this rule. What would help is to reduce the number of requirements for "performance improvement plans" and so forth while still rigidly enforcing the requirement that firing must be for cause. 

If an employee is not performing to standards, it should not take 2-3 years of poor performance evaluations to get rid of them. The government doesn't owe employees continued paychecks if they can't do the work properly, nor does it need to allow people to make lateral moves or even "fail up". What I would encourage the administration is to fix that specific issue: focus the process on whether an employee is fulfilling their duties and abiding by the relevant laws and standards of conduct. Allowing supervisors to remove poor performers is likely to produce a more efficient and effective workforce; allowing supervisors to remove anyone for any reason is likely to produce a sycophantic and potentially even corrupt workforce. If you care about performance and accountability, you should strongly consider hewing to the spirit of the merit-based system.

As long as there are any rules about which reasons are permissible to fire a person--and even under this rule there are certain distinctions such as not being able to fire a person based on their support for a president but still being able to fire a person based on their willingness to enact administration policies--there needs to be a transparent and accountable process that verifies whether the rules were adhered to. The less oversight and enforcement you have of policies to ensure decisions are based on performance, the more likely it is that bad actors will abuse the power conferred upon them to the detriment of the government and the American people at large.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
Comment Opposing RIN 3206-AO80: Violations of Merit Principles and Constitutional Protections
To Whom It May Concern:
I write in strong opposition to the Office of Personnel Management’s proposed rule (RIN: 3206-AO80) that would reclassify certain policy-influencing positions within the civil service into a new “Schedule Policy/Career,” stripping affected employees of statutory due process rights under 5 U.S.C. Chapters 43 and 75.
This proposal is not only contrary to the principles of the merit-based civil service system, but also legally deficient and constitutionally suspect.
1. Violation of 5 U.S.C. § 2301 – Merit System Principles
Federal employees serve under a system grounded in the merit principles codified at 5 U.S.C. § 2301, which require fair and open competition, protections against arbitrary action, and retention based on performance. Stripping civil servants of Chapter 43 and Chapter 75 rights contradicts § 2301(b)(2) and (b)(8), which ensure protection against arbitrary removal and prohibit actions based on political coercion or partisan influence.
Although the proposed rule purports to maintain nonpartisan hiring, the removal of due process protections converts these roles into de facto political appointments—an outcome that undermines the “nonpartisan, merit-based” civil service OPM claims to preserve.
2. Inconsistency with Oath of Office and Constitutional Mandates
Federal employees swear an oath under 5 U.S.C. § 3331 to “support and defend the Constitution of the United States.” This includes duties that may conflict with Presidential directives that are unconstitutional or unlawful. Penalizing employees for “undermining Presidential directives” (as referenced in the rule) invites abuse and contravenes the oath-bound responsibility to uphold the Constitution—not any single President’s agenda.
The Supreme Court has long held that public employees do not forfeit their constitutional protections. See Pickering v. Bd. of Educ., 391 U.S. 563 (1968). More recently, the Court reaffirmed that “the government may not condition public employment on a basis that infringes the employee’s constitutionally protected interest in freedom of expression.” Lane v. Franks, 573 U.S. 228, 236 (2014).
3. Due Process Violations – Deprivation Without Notice or Hearing
The proposed reclassification into “at-will” status deprives affected employees of their current property interest in continued federal employment without due process of law, violating the Fifth Amendment. See Cleveland Bd. of Educ. v. Loudermill, 470 U.S. 532 (1985) (holding that public employees with a property interest in their employment are entitled to notice and a hearing before termination).
4. Arbitrary and Capricious Under APA, 5 U.S.C. § 706
The proposed rule fails to demonstrate a reasoned analysis or empirical justification for overturning the comprehensive reforms adopted in OPM’s April 2024 final rule. Agencies already have authority under Chapters 43 and 75 to discipline and remove poor performers. The assertion that these tools are ineffective is speculative and unsupported by data. Agencies’ frustration with procedural requirements does not justify removing foundational due process protections for civil servants.
Moreover, the rule’s vague terminology—particularly “undermining the democratic process by subverting Presidential directives”—is both overbroad and chilling. It lacks the clarity and precision required of regulations that affect constitutional rights, see Grayned v. City of Rockford, 408 U.S. 104, 108–09 (1972).
5. Recommendations and Rewording
Rather than repealing Chapter 43 and 75 protections, OPM should consider administrative reforms that expedite current procedures without eliminating them entirely. The following revisions would preserve due process while addressing performance challenges:
•	Retain the April 2024 definitions limiting “policy-influencing positions” to political appointments.
•	Maintain Chapter 43 and 75 protections, but allow for streamlined timelines and mediation tools.
•	Define misconduct in objective, job-related terms rather than vague references to political disloyalty.
Conclusion
The proposed rule threatens the constitutional order, undermines the merit system, and reintroduces political patronage into the career civil service. I urge OPM to withdraw this proposal in its entirety or substantially revise it to preserve statutory and constitutional safeguards.

title: Comment from Roland Rurik
comment:
I oppose this proposed rule.

Civil service protections exist for a reason: to allow career experts to provide sound advice to their respective agencies and the administration, without the disruptions that would arise when leadership changes every four or eight years.  Political appointees are able to be dismissed at will, but extending this to include anyone working in a "confidential, policy-determining, policy-making, or policy-advocating character" would prevent those employees from providing reliable, unbiased policy opinions, without fear of retribution.  Removal of typical civil service protections will degrade the quality of applicants willing to fill those positions, and open opportunities for using government positions as a reward for political loyalty.  The extent of positions that would be considered "policy-influencing" is unclear, as is who is able to make the determination whether a position falls into that category, providing potential avenues for abuse.

The supplemental information states: "Surveys show few agency supervisors believe they could dismiss subordinates for serious misconduct or unacceptable performance."  It goes on to state that this undermines the merit system.  However, surveys on supervisor beliefs do not constitute data or evidence of actual harm.  It is wholly unclear whether the problem this proposed rule seeks to tackle even exists, and there is no evidence that, despite supervisor beliefs, individuals could not be removed for serious misconduct or poor performance. title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
Schedule F is unacceptable for the American public because it undermines the core principles of fairness, accountability, and transparency in government, which are essential for maintaining public trust and effective governance. The foundation of a democratic system is that the government serves the interests of all its citizens—not the interests of the ruling party or individuals in power. Schedule F threatens to fundamentally alter that balance by allowing politically motivated appointments to replace career civil servants, thus eroding the impartiality and professionalism that the public relies on.

First, Schedule F puts political loyalty ahead of competence. The American people expect their government to be run by qualified, knowledgeable professionals, not individuals selected based on their loyalty to the president or political party. By removing the protections that safeguard career civil servants, Schedule F opens the door to cronyism and favoritism, replacing skilled professionals with individuals whose primary qualification may simply be their political allegiance. This undermines the ability of government agencies to carry out their duties with integrity and effectiveness, which directly impacts the quality of services the public receives.

Second, Schedule F creates a government that is more susceptible to corruption. When positions of power are awarded based on political loyalty rather than expertise, the door is opened for decisions to be made based on personal or partisan interests rather than the needs of the American people. This weakens public confidence in the government, as people are less likely to trust a system that prioritizes political connections over the rule of law and public interest.

Moreover, this shift toward politicizing the federal workforce disrupts the stability and continuity of government operations. The public relies on consistent, reliable governance, especially in critical areas like national security, public health, and economic policy. Schedule F risks creating a revolving door of political appointees, with each administration bringing its own loyalists, leading to inefficiency, inconsistency, and delays in important services and decisions. This instability undermines the government’s ability to effectively address the needs of the public, particularly in times of crisis or when long-term planning is required.

In essence, Schedule F undermines the very principles of a fair and democratic government by politicizing the civil service, eroding the rule of law, and diminishing public trust. For the American public to have faith in their government, they must be assured that public servants are working in their best interests, not driven by partisan motives. The potential harm that Schedule F poses to the integrity and functionality of the government makes it unacceptable for the American people.

Ultimately, by reducing the efficiency of federal funding agencies and increasing the bureaucratic overhead, this plan  will devastate the scientific workforce and deleteriously harm national competitiveness.

When service members see that decisions impacting national security are driven by political motives rather than strategic considerations, it can create divisions and reduce the military’s overall readiness to respond effectively to national security threats.

In summary, Schedule F undermines military readiness by weakening the civilian support structures that ensure efficient defense operations, compromising expertise, stability, and continuity. The result is a less capable, less prepared military, which could have severe consequences in times of crisis or conflict.

title: Comment from Cole Shackleton
comment:
I firmly oppose the introduction or reinstatement of the 'Schedule F' classification for federal employees. This proposal endangers the merit-based civil service system that has supported a professional, impartial federal workforce for over a century.

The creation of Schedule F fundamentally undermines the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883, which was designed to eliminate the spoils system and establish merit-based hiring. Reclassifying career civil servants—especially those in policy-making or analytical roles—without cause invites politically motivated hiring and firing. This directly contradicts the principle of an apolitical civil service, as outlined in 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8), which mandates that federal employment decisions remain merit-driven and free from political interference.

Additionally, the vague and expansive criteria for Schedule F inclusion violate the due process protections enshrined in 5 U.S.C. § 7513, which requires just cause and procedural safeguards for removing career employees. Denying these protections weakens accountability and discourages honest, expert advice, ultimately jeopardizing the effectiveness of government operations.

Moreover, the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) is mandated by 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq. to uphold merit system principles. Implementing Schedule F not only contradicts this statutory mission but also subjects career professionals to undue political pressure, threatening the integrity and continuity of federal programs across administrations.

In summary, Schedule F poses a severe threat to good governance, civil service independence, and the rule of law. I urge the administration and OPM to reject any efforts to implement or revive this perilous classification.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
Schedule F threatens election security by politicizing the federal workforce, particularly in agencies responsible for overseeing and safeguarding the electoral process. By reclassifying tens of thousands of civil servants as “at-will” employees, the policy allows for the removal of experienced professionals who manage critical aspects of election administration, such as voter registration, ballot security, and election monitoring. This creates a system where positions can be filled based on political loyalty rather than expertise, undermining the impartiality essential to free and fair elections.

The politicization of these roles increases the risk of partisan interference in the electoral process. When individuals are appointed based on political allegiance rather than merit, decisions regarding election procedures and safeguards may be influenced by partisan interests, potentially compromising the integrity of elections. Such actions could lead to the manipulation of voting systems, suppression of voter turnout, or the undermining of election results, all of which threaten the foundational principles of democracy.

Furthermore, the erosion of civil service protections under Schedule F may deter qualified professionals from entering or remaining in public service. The uncertainty and politicization associated with these positions can discourage individuals committed to upholding democratic values from working in election-related roles, leading to a loss of institutional knowledge and expertise. This degradation of the federal workforce not only weakens the capacity to administer elections effectively but also diminishes public confidence in the electoral system.

In summary, Schedule F poses a significant threat to election security by introducing political considerations into the administration of elections, increasing the potential for partisan interference, and undermining the professionalism and integrity of the federal workforce. Safeguarding the impartiality and competence of election officials is crucial to maintaining the trust of the American public in the electoral process.

comment:

By reclassifying these roles as political appointments under Schedule F, the protections and stability that military spouses depend on could be severely undermined. Since these positions would become vulnerable to dismissal based on political loyalty rather than merit, military spouses working in these positions could face job insecurity, making it more difficult for them to maintain consistent employment. This insecurity could discourage military spouses from pursuing careers in government altogether or force them to leave positions they’ve worked hard to attain, further compounding the financial and emotional strain of military life.

Moreover, military spouses already face high rates of unemployment and underemployment due to the frequent relocations required by military service. Schedule F could exacerbate these challenges by limiting job opportunities in the public sector, which many military spouses rely on for stable, fulfilling employment. The loss of protections for these positions could discourage federal agencies from hiring military spouses in the first place, further contributing to the existing barriers they face in securing long-term, stable employment.

In essence, Schedule F would create an environment where military spouses are more vulnerable to job loss and instability, exacerbating the already significant challenges they face in building a career while supporting their service member. This could worsen the economic insecurity of military families and hinder efforts to support and empower military spouses in the workforce.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
Schedule F is inherently detrimental because it fundamentally undermines the values of fairness, trust, and integrity in government. These values are not just matters of policy—they are core principles that define the relationship between the government and the public. When people lose faith in the government’s ability to function impartially and in the best interests of the people, it erodes the very foundation of democracy.

The American public relies on the belief that the government is there to serve everyone, not just those in power or those with political connections. A government that hires and fires based on political loyalty, rather than merit and expertise, sends a message that the public service is a tool for partisan gain rather than an impartial institution working for the common good. This is not just an issue of efficiency or economics—it strikes at the heart of what it means to live in a democracy. If the civil service becomes politically motivated, it no longer serves as a neutral body that implements the will of the people, regardless of political affiliation. Instead, it becomes a tool of the ruling party.

The trust of the American people in their government is fragile and, once lost, is incredibly difficult to rebuild. The public deserves to know that when policies are enacted, they are based on expertise, fairness, and long-term strategy, not on political loyalty or personal gain. When that trust is compromised, the very legitimacy of the government is at risk. Schedule F doesn’t just undermine government efficiency or waste money—it directly threatens the social contract between the government and the governed, and that is an argument that cannot be countered with facts or figures. The loss of trust, once it occurs, is irreversible, and the consequences of eroding public confidence in the impartiality of government are far-reaching and profound.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
Schedule F is a costly policy that wastes taxpayer money by introducing inefficiency, instability, and poor decision-making into the federal workforce. One of the primary costs associated with Schedule F is the increased turnover it would create within federal agencies. By enabling political loyalty to override merit-based hiring and job protections, many experienced professionals would be replaced with individuals who may lack the necessary expertise or experience. This constant turnover results in higher recruitment, training, and onboarding costs as new hires must be brought in and brought up to speed.

Additionally, the loss of institutional knowledge and continuity under Schedule F leads to inefficiencies in the execution of government programs. Experienced civil servants play an essential role in implementing policies, managing budgets, and overseeing long-term projects. When these positions are filled by individuals with little to no experience or institutional memory, government programs are more likely to face delays, mismanagement, and unnecessary costs. Instead of leveraging the knowledge and experience of long-standing professionals to ensure efficient and effective outcomes, the government would be forced to reinvent the wheel with each change in personnel.

Another hidden cost of Schedule F is the potential for a more politically driven and fragmented bureaucracy. When government functions are influenced by political appointments, agencies may prioritize partisan goals over effective policy implementation, leading to poor allocation of resources. Taxpayer dollars could be wasted on inefficient projects, redundant services, or initiatives driven by short-term political agendas rather than long-term value for the public.

Finally, the decreased morale and uncertainty within the civil service under Schedule F would lead to lower productivity and increased absenteeism. As government employees worry about job security and the potential for politically motivated firings, their ability to focus on their duties diminishes, leading to lower output and reduced quality of service.

In essence, Schedule F wastes taxpayer money by creating inefficiencies, increasing turnover, reducing the quality of government programs, and encouraging politically motivated decisions that serve partisan interests rather than the public good. The ultimate result is a less effective, more costly government that is unable to provide the services and outcomes that Americans need and deserve.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
Schedule F increases inefficiencies in government operations by undermining the stability, expertise, and continuity necessary for effective governance. When positions are politicized and filled based on political loyalty rather than qualifications, it leads to the replacement of experienced civil servants with individuals who may lack the necessary expertise or knowledge to manage complex issues. This disruption not only reduces the overall effectiveness of government agencies but also results in a loss of institutional memory—vital for making informed, efficient decisions.

First, the constant turnover that Schedule F creates—where employees can be dismissed for political reasons—hinders the long-term planning required for effective governance. Key positions are filled based on political considerations rather than merit, meaning that skilled professionals with years of experience and knowledge are replaced by individuals who may lack the institutional understanding and specialized skills needed to tackle important issues. This lack of continuity leads to inefficiencies, delays, and poor decision-making because new appointees may need extensive time to learn the complexities of their roles and rebuild relationships with colleagues, industry experts, and the public.

Second, politicizing the civil service contributes to a lack of accountability and focus. When employees are worried about losing their jobs due to political reasons, they are less likely to make decisions that are in the public interest or to take the necessary risks to implement bold, innovative policies. A politicized workforce is more likely to avoid tough decisions or implement policies based on short-term political goals rather than long-term solutions. This inefficiency slows down the implementation of programs that benefit citizens, wastes taxpayer money, and prevents government agencies from performing their jobs effectively.

Lastly, the erosion of a merit-based civil service also discourages highly skilled professionals from seeking or staying in public service positions. If employees know their job security is dependent on political loyalty, rather than their abilities and expertise, they may leave for the private sector or refuse to enter government roles altogether. This brain drain further compounds inefficiencies, as government agencies lose highly qualified individuals who are critical to driving progress and managing complex operations.

In sum, Schedule F makes government less efficient by destabilizing the workforce, reducing the quality of decision-making, and discouraging top talent from remaining in public service. The resulting inefficiencies ultimately hurt the public, leading to slower responses to crises, higher costs, and poorer outcomes.
