[ATTACHMENT: attachment_1.pdf]
Comment on Improving Performance, Accountability and Responsiveness in the
Civil Service
Docket Number: OPM-2025-0004
This comment is submitted in response to OPM’s proposed rule, which asserts the goal
of improving performance, accountability, and responsiveness within the federal civil
service. The proposed changes claim to update and reinforce civil service practices, yet
they risk destabilizing a system that has long relied on clear, merit-based protections. In
addressing concerns over underperformance and the handling of problematic
employees, the proposal institutes a broad overhaul rather than implementing focused,
targeted reforms. A more specific set of reforms would promote accountability and
responsiveness while preserving the essential stability of the nonpartisan, merit-based
workforce.
Neglected Reliance Interests and Stakeholder Implications
Federal employees and the American public have long depended on a stable, merit-
based civil service system. This rule disregards these critical interests by dismantling due
process protections from politicized job actions—the very cornerstones of federal
employment. It sends a clear message: that career civil servants are undervalued and
expendable.
This concern is compounded by alarming rhetoric; for example, President Trump
recently stated on Truth Social—reported by Axios—that “if these government workers
refuse to advance the policy interests of the President, or are engaging in corrupt
behavior, they should no longer have a job. This is common sense, and will allow the
federal government to finally be ‘run like a business.’” Coupled with mass layoffs and
reclassifications, such messaging has sown tremendous and persistent distrust and
uncertainty within the workforce.
The resulting instability not only demoralizes current employees but also erodes the
capacity of federal agencies to carry out essential and effective services. By undermining
the very framework that has long ensured a professional and nonpartisan civil service,
the rule alienates key stakeholders who depend on the continuity and integrity of
government operations. It is a direct affront to the principles of fairness and reliability
that underpin public trust in federal institutions.
1
Ambiguities in Defining Policy-Influencing Roles
The proposed rule employs vague, overly broad, poorly-defined terms like “policy-
making,” “policy-determining,” and “policy-advocating” to classify positions subject to
revised civil service protections. Such imprecise language risks arbitrary reclassification
and punitive actions. Recent reports suggest that the Administration has instructed
agencies to begin reclassifying tens of thousands of federal employees under such
pretexts, stripping them of job protections. The absence of narrowly tailored and clearly
defined criteria for identifying “policy influencing” positions invites inconsistent
applications across agencies and administrations, thereby raising the specter of
politically motivated decisions that undermine the nonpartisan protections essential to
our merit-based system.
Statutory Authority and Separation of Powers
While the Office of Personnel Management derives its authority from the Civil Service
Reform Act and the Administrative Procedure Act, the rule’s application of that
authority is alarming and inconsistent with longstanding statutory principles. Rather
than a measured, evidence-based approach, OPM is transforming career positions into
at-will roles for policy-influencing employees en masse—a marked departure from the
protections Congress enshrined. Recent litigation further underscores this ultra vires
action, with unions arguing that nullifying established protections without proper
notice violates statutory limits and subverts Congress’s intent.
This overreach not only exceeds the statutory authority, but also serves as a desperate,
grasping attempt to unconstitutionally concentrate power within the executive branch,
bypassing the essential checks and balances that underpin our constitutional system.
This is something our nation’s founders specifically warned about, and designed the
Constitution to try to prevent.
Recent news reports document concerns raised by experts and policymakers alike,
warning that such expansive reinterpretation essentially grants political appointees
unfettered authority to remove employees on a whim, eroding decades-old safeguards.
This shift is a dangerous encroachment upon the separation of powers, one that
jeopardizes the impartiality and durability of the merit-based civil service.
Statutory and Constitutional Authority Concerns
The proposed rule attempts to justify stripping essential job protections by invoking
Section 3302 of the Civil Service Reform Act and related statutory provisions.
2
However, this interpretation stretches the language far beyond its intended purpose and
completely disregards the constitutional safeguards integral to our federal employment
system. By effectively authorizing discretionary, unchecked executive control over
personnel decisions, the rule bypasses the due process and judicial review for career
employees. Many commentators see this expansive reading as a gross overreach—a
deliberate circumvention of Congress’s intent to balance efficiency with fairness.
Overreliance on Presidential Discretion and Erosion of Checks and Balances
The rule’s concentration of power in the executive branch is most alarming. By
converting policy influencing positions into at-will roles and dismantling established
adverse action procedures, it grants unfettered discretion to the President and his
appointees—leaving little room for judicial or legislative oversight. This centralization
transforms the merit-based system into a politically volatile instrument. In practice, such
an erosion of institutional checks and balances not only compromises the longstanding
impartiality of federal service but also invites arbitrary, partisan actions that threaten
the integrity of our democratic institutions. The stakes are too high for a system that
should protect career civil servants from transient political impulses. The statutory and
constitutional overreaches raise profound questions about executive power, but they
also translate directly into challenges for daily operations and internal workforce
stability.
Balancing Merit System Principles with Accountability
Federal agencies are said to face challenges managing underperformance and addressing
misconduct—issues raised in Federal Employee Viewpoint Surveys. The current system
can sometimes shift poor performers rather than remedying shortcomings with timely,
targeted performance improvement plans.
The proposed rule seeks to enhance accountability by reclassifying policy influencing
positions to allow for swift removal from critical roles. However, this approach risks
undermining the essential balance between ensuring rapid corrective measures and
maintaining robust procedural safeguards. Rapid removals may sometimes be necessary,
yet, if pursued in a manner that diminishes objective, performance-based evaluations,
they can incentivize arbitrary decisions and invite political manipulation into a system
that must remain insulated from transient partisanship.
A wiser, more measured approach would involve targeted reforms to streamline and
enforce existing performance improvement procedures without a wholesale alteration
of civil service protections. Strengthening mechanisms such as clearly defined
3
performance improvement plans and enhanced supervisory training can improve
accountability without eroding the stability and fairness integral to the federal
workforce.
Recommendations for a Balanced, Enduring Reform
Given the significant concerns raised by the proposed rule, a more measured, targeted
approach is required. Rather than embracing a one-size-fits-all radical overhaul, OPM
must return to a framework that emphasizes sound performance management while
safeguarding due process.
OPM should engage directly with congressional oversight bodies and labor
representatives in a genuine, transparent dialogue—one that prioritizes the long-term
stability and nonpartisan integrity of our civil service. Concrete measures should
include enhanced supervisory training and robust performance improvement plans.
Moreover, OPM must ensure that any future revisions adhere rigorously to the notice-
and-comment requirements of the Administrative Procedure Act—an obvious
imperative underscored by recent litigation—to safeguard the legitimacy and longevity of
the merit-based system.
Questionable Economic and Operational Assumptions
The rule is premised on the notion that stripping certain protections will yield modest
cost savings, streamlined separations, and reduced litigation—thus promising enhanced
agency performance. However, these assumptions are flawed. Increased turnover, the
loss of institutional knowledge, and a surge in litigation can rapidly outweigh any short-
term efficiencies gained from shifting to at-will employment. Rather than delivering
genuine operational improvements, the rule risks creating a façade of fiscal prudence
while sowing the seeds for long-term dysfunction. The hidden costs—including
diminished employee morale, reduced agency effectiveness, and the destabilization of
key government functions—are likely to impose a far heavier burden on federal
operations.
Challenges to Future Recruitment and Perceptions of Federal Service
The rule sends a negative message to all prospective federal employees, especially recent
graduates. Disparaging rhetoric from both the Administration and Congress, alongside
policies that imply federal workers are expendable, may deter talented and committed
individuals from considering federal service. The proposed rule, along with the
messaging, implicitly suggests that federal workers are no longer valued—that the system
4
has shifted from one of professional respect to one of disregard, as though “we don’t
want you.” This message risks more than just tarnishing morale; it will shrink the pool
of talented, committed individuals willing to serve the public, thereby imperiling the
long-term efficacy and neutrality of our federal workforce. Any reform efforts should
not only address performance challenges but also actively reinforce the message that
federal service remains a stable, worthy, and respected career path.
Conclusion
In short, the proposed rule represents a sweeping departure from the core principles of
merit-based employment and due process that have long underpinned federal service.
Its broad, imprecise definitions and politically charged revisions risk transforming the
federal workforce into an instrument of arbitrary, partisan manipulation, rather than
genuine accountability. Reforms should uphold fairness, predictability, and
nonpartisan integrity, rather than enabling arbitrary removals and destabilizing internal
structures.
Thank you for considering my comments.
Michael Ravnitzky
Silver Spring, Maryland

title: Comment from Heidi Henninger
comment:
I'm writing to vehemently oppose the return to the “Schedule F” classification for non-political federal employees. This proposal threatens the merit-based civil service system that has underpinned the nonpartisan federal workforce for over a century and threatens to reclassify many positions that should not be held by political appointees.

Looking to our present laws, the proposed Schedule F directly would undermine the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883, which was enacted to combat the spoils system and establish a merit-based hiring process for federal employees. By allowing a broad swath of career civil servants—particularly those involved in policy-making or analysis—to be reclassified and potentially terminated without cause, Schedule F opens the door to politically motivated hiring and firing. This is antithetical to the principle of an apolitical civil service enshrined in 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8) and violates the due process protections guaranteed by 5 U.S.C. § 7513, which requires cause for the removal of career federal employees. Stripping thousands of workers of these protections not only weakens accountability but also risks chilling expert advice and dissent within agencies—undermining the very effectiveness of government operations.

The Office of Personnel Management (OPM) is also bound by 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq. to support the merit system principles. Implementing Schedule F contradicts this statutory mission and places undue political pressure on career professionals, compromising the integrity and continuity of federal programs across administrations.

This proposal is completely counter to the regulations cited above, good governance and civil service independence. I oppose this proposed rule and urge the Administration to refrain from moving forward with reclassifications.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
I am firmly opposed to any effort to implement or reinstate the “Schedule F” classification for federal employees. Such a measure would erode the merit-based framework that has sustained a competent, impartial civil service for more than a century.

Schedule F represents a significant departure from the reforms introduced by the Pendleton Act of 1883, which was designed to dismantle the spoils system and promote merit-based hiring within the federal government. By reclassifying a broad segment of the career workforce—particularly those involved in policy-related functions—Schedule F would enable their removal without cause, inviting politically driven employment decisions. This runs counter to the principles laid out in 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8), which emphasize hiring and firing based on merit rather than political loyalty.

Additionally, the proposed criteria for inclusion under Schedule F are overly broad and imprecise, violating the due process rights established by 5 U.S.C. § 7513. These protections are vital to ensuring that civil servants can offer expert opinions and dissenting views without fear of retaliation. Undermining these safeguards would significantly impair the effectiveness and integrity of government operations.

The Office of Personnel Management (OPM) is tasked under 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq. with upholding the merit system principles. Endorsing Schedule F would contradict that statutory responsibility and compromise the impartiality and professionalism of the civil service by subjecting it to increased political interference.

In summary, Schedule F poses a serious threat to the core tenets of a fair and functional civil service, including political neutrality, institutional stability, and adherence to the rule of law. I urge the administration and OPM to reject any regulatory proposal that would move this harmful classification forward.

title: Comment from Susan B
comment:
The proposed “Schedule Policy/Career” classification would be a disastrous policy to implement.By allowing political leadership to reclassify large numbers of career civil servants—particularly those involved in policy development or analysis—this measure would remove critical job protections and expose federal employees to politically motivated hiring and firing. Career civil servants take an oath to serve the public in a nonpartisan way. 
Federal jobs should be awarded based on merit, not political allegiance. Civil servants are hired for their expertise, and they’re protected from being fired without cause—so they can give honest advice and keep government running smoothly through political transitions.
The “Schedule Policy/Career” classification would reverse that progress. It would let agencies reclassify civil servants in policy-related roles, removing due process protections and turning them into at-will employees. In practical terms, that means thousands of experts could be fired just for holding views that don’t align with the current administration—or simply to make room for political loyalists.
There are  principles in U.S. law that protect civil servants from political coercion. It also puts the Office of Personnel Management in a conflicted role, as it’s tasked with upholding the very merit principles this proposal undermines.
But the problem goes deeper than legal conflict—it’s about how government works. If you politicize expert roles, you discourage facts, truth-telling, and long-term thinking. Employees may become afraid to speak up, especially when they’re delivering unwelcome news. And when people are hired for loyalty instead of competence, the quality of decisions and public services suffers.
This affects all of us and puts the public at risk. Worse, the cost-benefit of government services could decline, as programs staffed by politically appointed loyalists are more likely to be inefficient, error-prone, or wasteful. We all end up paying more—either in tax dollars or in poor outcomes—for less effective government.
While this kind of policy might be introduced under a conservative administration, a future democratic administration could just as easily use it to reward its own political allies. That’s what makes this proposal so dangerous—it’s not about one party or one president. It’s about breaking a system that protects us all by ensuring federal workers are focused on public service, not political loyalty. You could end up with massive firings every time a different political party takes power.
Government needs continuity, expertise, and stability—especially in times of crisis. The “Schedule Policy/Career” proposal would undermine all of that. It would erode trust, drive out talent, and make our civil service weaker and less effective.
We should reject this Schedule Policy/Career proposal outright. We need to uphold merit and protect impartiality.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
Dear Office of Personnel Management,

I write in opposition to the proposed rule titled “Improving Performance, Accountability, and Responsiveness in the Civil Service” (RIN 3206-AO80). While the stated purpose is to enhance efficiency, the proposed changes would instead undermine the impartiality and professionalism of the federal civil service. Converting “policy-influencing” positions into at-will roles, subject to removal without due process, risks injecting political influence into roles that have historically been guided by expertise and nonpartisan judgment.

The merit-based system, a cornerstone of good governance since the Pendleton Act, ensures that civil servants are chosen and retained for their qualifications, not their political loyalties. The new Schedule Policy/Career proposal would erode these protections, allowing arbitrary dismissals that compromise the stability and credibility of federal agencies. History has shown that politicizing the civil service leads to inefficiency, corruption, and a loss of public trust. Stripping independent protections would discourage whistleblowing, reduce long-term expertise, and deter highly skilled professionals from entering public service.

I urge the Office of Personnel Management to withdraw this proposed rule and instead pursue reforms that preserve the civil service’s integrity and independence. Accountability can be improved through better training, clearer performance standards, and streamlined management processes—not by dismantling the safeguards that ensure impartiality and professionalism in our government workforce.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
The proposed rule “Improving Performance, Accountability, and Responsiveness in the Civil Service” represents a paradigm shift in federal personnel policy – one that, despite its optimistic title, would likely degrade performance, undermine true accountability, and reduce responsiveness to the public by subordinating career employees to partisan control. The danger of eroding the separation between politics and administration cannot be overstated. It risks transforming a merit-based civil service into a patronage workforce where expertise is subordinated to loyalty tests. History has shown the damage a politicized bureaucracy can do – from the rampant corruption and incompetence of the 19th-century spoils era ￼ ￼, to the constitutional violations that occur when officials use public offices as political weapons ￼ ￼. It is for good reason that reformers built a system to prevent those abuses. A nonpartisan civil service is not a partisan issue; it is a fundamental institutional safeguard that benefits any administration that governs in good faith and every citizen who relies on unbiased governance.

Ultimately, the goals of performance, accountability, and responsiveness in government are best served by empowering professional civil servants to do their jobs free of improper political interference, not by rendering them servile to political appointees. An effective civil service is one where employees can be held to high standards – indeed, the merit system demands high performance and ethical conduct – but also one where employees can challenge unlawful or unwise directives without fear of baseless removal. True accountability in the civil service means accountability to the laws and the American people, not just to the momentary occupants of high office. And responsiveness should be toward the public’s needs and the nation’s long-term interests, which a professional civil service is uniquely positioned to understand, rather than a narrow responsiveness to partisan commands.

In view of these concerns, this critique strongly urges that the proposed rule be reconsidered and withdrawn. Any civil service reforms should fortify, not weaken, the merit-based, apolitical character of our federal workforce. Instead of dismantling protections, we should invest in better training for managers, streamlined but fair procedures, and recruitment of skilled personnel – steps that can improve performance without politicization. The stakes are high: if implemented, this rule could inflict lasting harm on the integrity of the civil service and, by extension, the health of American democracy. As the Pendleton Act architects knew well, to protect our republic we must ensure that government positions are filled by those loyal to the Constitution and public service, not to party bosses. The wall between partisan politics and the professional civil service was built deliberately and with bipartisan wisdom; it should not be torn down. Preserving an independent, professional civil service is essential to guard against political interference and abuse, and to uphold a government that is of the people, by the people, and for all the people – not just for the victors of the latest election.

title: Comment from Kelly Ross
comment:
As a friend of a federal employee, I’m concerned that the proposed Schedule Policy/Career rule (RIN: 3206-AO80) is too broad and could harm non-policy staff by removing long-standing civil service protections.

Many federal workers serve in and analytical, operational, and technical roles that do not involve policy-making. Yet there are reports of mass lists being prepared for reclassification—regardless of official duties. This threatens employee rights and disrupts the services the public depends on.

OPM must define “policy-influencing” using position description language, as required by 5 U.S.C. § 7511(b)(2). Without tying this designation to documented duties, the rule risks misclassifying workers unlawfully and invites legal and operational issues. The Supreme Court has required narrow interpretation of such exemptions (see Fausto, 484 U.S. 439 (1988)).

Please revise the rule to:

- Limit Schedule Policy/Career to positions with explicit policy-making duties

- Prohibit bulk reclassification by name

- Require a redress process for wrongful designation

- Maintain transparency through public reporting

I have detailed 5 additional concerns below that I would like you to address.

1. Lack of Impact Analysis on DEIA (Diversity, Equity, Inclusion, and Accessibility)

Substantiated Concern:

The proposed rule does not include any analysis of how removing adverse action protections might disproportionately impact underrepresented groups. Given the federal government’s commitments under Executive Order 14035 (DEIA in the Federal Workforce), and Title VII of the Civil Rights Act, OPM must assess whether employees from protected classes are more likely to be included in Schedule Policy/Career designations or disproportionately targeted for removal. Failure to assess disparate impact may violate procedural due process and expose the rule to challenge.

2. Inconsistency with Past OPM Policy and Regulatory History

Substantiated Concern:

Just one year ago, OPM finalized the April 2024 Rule that defined policy-influencing positions as exclusive to political appointees. The proposed reversal lacks a rigorous explanation of why that policy—grounded in statutory interpretation and the administrative record—should be discarded. Under FCC v. Fox Television Stations, 556 U.S. 502 (2009), agencies must provide a “reasoned explanation” for policy reversals, especially when they disrupt prior reliance interests. The preamble of the 2025 rule references a change in presidential preference but does not meet the required legal threshold for overturning its own recent regulatory interpretation.

3. Lack of Cost-Benefit or Workforce Impact Analysis

Substantiated Concern:

The proposed rule contains no quantitative estimate of the number of federal positions likely to be reclassified, the costs of turnover, litigation, or reduced morale. The Regulatory Flexibility Act (5 U.S.C. §§ 601–612) and Executive Orders 12866 and 13563 require agencies to assess economic and administrative impacts of significant rules. Without such analysis, the rule may be arbitrary and capricious under the APA.

4. Conflict with Constitutional Due Process Principles

Substantiated Concern:

Removing Chapter 43 and 75 protections without offering any meaningful opportunity for notice, response, or appeal may violate employees’ property interest in continued employment, recognized under Arnett v. Kennedy, 416 U.S. 134 (1974), and reaffirmed in Cleveland Board of Education v. Loudermill, 470 U.S. 532 (1985). Career status typically confers this interest. The proposed rule claims reclassified employees remain “career,” yet strips their procedural protections, creating a due process inconsistency OPM must resolve.

5. Lack of Guidance to Prevent Misclassification

Substantiated Concern:

The proposed rule allows agencies to propose positions for Schedule Policy/Career without requiring a formal checklist, rubric, or crosswalk to determine eligibility. Inconsistent application across agencies will lead to confusion, morale issues, and increased litigation risk. OPM has historically provided interpretive guidance for other excepted service authorities (e.g., Pathways, Schedule A hiring). It should do the same here or risk violating the APA’s “arbitrary and capricious” standard due to lack of implementation clarity.

Federal workers deserve fairness, and the public deserves a stable, effective government. Thank you for considering this comment.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
Please see attached.



--- ATTACHMENTS ---

[ATTACHMENT: attachment_1.pdf]
I write to express serious legal concerns regarding a specific provision of the proposed rule
published on April 23, 2025 (90 FR 17182), which delegates final authority over placement into
Schedule Policy/Career to the President. This comment addresses the following provision:
“In a structural difference with the original Executive Order 13957, the President—not OPM—will
now move positions into Schedule Policy/Career. Pursuant to that Executive Order, agencies
will review their workforces and petition OPM to recommend that the President move specific
positions into Schedule Policy/Career. OPM will review these petitions and make the
recommendations it deems appropriate. However, the President will make the final decision
about which positions go into Schedule Policy/Career. That decision will be effectuated by a new
executive order issued under Presidential—not OPM—authority.”
This provision raises multiple legal concerns that warrant the immediate reconsideration and
withdrawal of this aspect of the proposal.
1. Conflict with the Civil Service Reform Act (CSRA) and Title 5
The Civil Service Reform Act of 1978 (CSRA) assigns the Office of Personnel Management
(OPM)—not the President—statutory responsibility to administer the federal civil service. Under
5 U.S.C. §§ 1103 and 1302, OPM is tasked with prescribing regulations to carry out civil service
laws, overseeing personnel practices, and ensuring compliance with merit system principles.
By giving the President unilateral authority to move positions into Schedule Policy/Career, the
proposal bypasses the regulatory authority that Congress expressly vested in OPM. Civil service
rules are not meant to be redefined through executive order alone—particularly not when the
effect is to strip career employees of procedural rights.
This shift in authority is not merely procedural. It changes the character of thousands of civil
service positions and removes them from statutory protections. Such a structural alteration to
the civil service framework requires congressional action or, at a minimum, formal rulemaking by
OPM subject to public notice and comment—not unilateral executive fiat.
2. Separation of Powers and Nondelegation Concerns
The proposed rule allows the President to take final action based on agency petitions and OPM
review, culminating in a new executive order for each classification change. This raises
significant separation of powers concerns:
Civil service protections were created by statute, and changes to those protections should be
made by legislative amendment or regulatory action, not individualized executive orders.
Allowing the President to decide on a case-by-case basis which career positions lose due
process protections under chapters 43 and 75 is a quasi-legislative function, for which the
President lacks direct statutory authority.
This approach risks violating the principle established in Youngstown Sheet & Tube Co. v.
Sawyer, 343 U.S. 579 (1952), in which the Supreme Court held that the President may not
exercise lawmaking power independently of Congress or contrary to statutory limits. Here, the
President is acting outside the bounds of Title 5 by reshaping employee protections without
congressional delegation.
3. Lack of Procedural Safeguards and Public Transparency
By empowering the President to classify positions through executive orders, this process
evades the requirements of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), including:
Notice-and-comment rulemaking;
Public availability of rationale and supporting data;
Judicial review of agency action.
Because each decision would be issued as a presidential action rather than a regulatory rule,
affected employees and the public would have no opportunity to object, and the action may be
insulated from judicial review. This lack of procedural safeguards undermines the transparency,
accountability, and fairness required of federal rulemaking and administrative action.
4. Potential for Political Abuse
The proposal's centralization of classification authority in the President—without adherence to
OPM’s independent processes—opens the door to politically motivated or retaliatory
reclassifications of civil servants. Even if agency heads or OPM conduct objective reviews, the
final classification decision becomes inherently political when issued directly by the White
House.
Such a structure violates the spirit of the Pendleton Act of 1883 and the merit system principles
in 5 U.S.C. § 2301, which protect employees from discrimination, retaliation, or removal based
on political views or affiliations.
Conclusion
Delegating final classification authority to the President in this manner is contrary to statutory
mandates, undermines essential due process rights, and politicizes a system designed to
ensure impartial and competent public service. This approach constitutes a major departure

title: Comment from Romeo Tango
comment:
I strongly oppose the implementation or revival of the “Schedule F” classification for federal employees. This proposal threatens the merit-based civil service system that has underpinned a professional, nonpartisan federal workforce for over a century.

First and foremost, the creation of Schedule F directly undermines the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883, which was enacted to combat the spoils system and establish a merit-based hiring process for federal employees. By allowing a broad swath of career civil servants—particularly those involved in policy-making or analysis—to be reclassified and potentially terminated without cause, Schedule F opens the door to politically motivated hiring and firing. This is antithetical to the principle of an apolitical civil service enshrined in 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8), which mandates that federal employment decisions be based on merit and free from political influence.

Moreover, the vague and sweeping criteria for inclusion in Schedule F violate the due process protections guaranteed by 5 U.S.C. § 7513, which requires cause and procedural safeguards for the removal of career federal employees. Stripping thousands of workers of these protections not only weakens accountability but also risks chilling expert advice and dissent within agencies—undermining the very effectiveness of government operations.

The Office of Personnel Management (OPM) is also bound by 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq. to support the merit system principles. Implementing Schedule F contradicts this statutory mission and places undue political pressure on career professionals, compromising the integrity and continuity of federal programs across administrations.

In conclusion, the Schedule F proposal poses a grave threat to the foundational principles of good governance, civil service independence, and the rule of law. I urge the administration and OPM to reject any regulatory framework that seeks to implement or revive this dangerous classification.

title: Comment from Maxine Giammo
comment:
I am writing to formally oppose the proposed rule OPM-2025-0004, which seeks to reintroduce elements of the revoked Schedule F classification. This rule would unlawfully erode the merit-based foundations of the federal civil service and enable mass politicized firings under the false premise of managerial discretion.

As a former employee of both the National Park Service and the Department of the Interior, and as a citizen whose father and sister have served long careers within these same institutions, I have firsthand knowledge of the critical importance of a nonpartisan civil service. My family has dedicated itself to preserving the integrity of public service—something this rule actively undermines.

Under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), this agency is legally required to respond to all substantive comments, including this one. As a matter of law, I assert that this proposed rule is arbitrary and capricious for the following reasons:
	1.	It violates the merit system principles under 5 U.S.C. § 2301 by creating a class of employees who may be fired without cause or recourse. This effectively circumvents due process protections and destabilizes the career service workforce.
	2.	It invites unconstitutional patronage practices by enabling partisan purges of expert staff under the guise of managerial discretion. This is functionally incompatible with the values enshrined in the Pendleton Act and modern civil service law.
	3.	It lacks a rational basis or empirical justification. No evidence has been presented to suggest that performance or accountability in the civil service is meaningfully improved by politicizing career roles. On the contrary, federal data show that career employees serve with dedication across administrations, regardless of party.
	4.	It was previously rejected for good reason. The original Schedule F was roundly criticized by legal experts, career officials, and good governance groups across the political spectrum. It was revoked in early 2021 for threatening democratic norms and weakening public trust in federal institutions.

On a personal note, this proposal threatens the livelihoods of public servants like my father and sister—people who have dedicated their careers to protecting public lands, water systems, and cultural resources. To call their roles “policy-determining” simply because they work in high-level, mission-critical positions is not only inaccurate, it’s insulting. These are not partisan actors; they are professionals whose service has spanned multiple administrations.

This rule would place loyal public servants under a sword of Damocles, where survival depends not on merit, but political loyalty. That is antithetical to the rule of law.

I urge OPM to withdraw this proposed rule immediately. Should it move forward, you are legally obligated to address this comment in your rulemaking record under the APA.

Thank you for your attention—and for upholding what remains of the civil service ideal.

title: Comment from Shanna  Yule
comment:
I'm providing a number of quotes from this proposed rule and policy change, to which I'm highly opposed to seeing be implemented. They appear illegal and in opposition to our Constitution,  to our way of American life. 

1)   "In a structural difference with the original Executive Order 13957, the President—not OPM—will now move positions into Schedule Policy/Career. Pursuant to that Executive Order, agencies will review their workforces and petition OPM to recommend that the President move specific positions into Schedule Policy/Career. OPM will review these petitions and make the recommendations it deems appropriate.[80] However, the President will make the final decision about which positions go into Schedule Policy/Career. That decision will be effectuated by a new executive order issued under Presidential—not OPM—authority."

2)   "OPM previously argued that even if chapter 43 and 75 procedures made addressing poor performance or misconduct difficult, the appropriate solution would be to try to convince Congress of that proposition and work for corresponding legislative changes to title 5.[127]"

3)   "It also expressly describes what is and is not required of Schedule Policy/Career employees. They “are not required to personally or politically support the current President or the policies of the current administration. They are required to faithfully implement administration policies to the best of their ability, consistent with their constitutional oath and the vesting of executive authority solely in the President. Failure to do so is grounds for dismissal.” [76]"

4)   "bureaucratic autonomy is beneficial. Some argue it creates a beneficial “internal separation of powers” within the executive branch.[136] Others argue that bureaucratic autonomy moderates policy swings between administrations.[137]"


These quotes are the basics of this policy change,  as I see them,  and in my reading, it seems Congress should retain the power to maintain the oversight. If the President wants to effectuate these change,  he should take it up with Congress. 

In addition, the Constitution is what oaths are offered to in our country.  We do not swear oaths to the President. This policy seems to outline that if employees are seen to be protecting the rights and policies that uphold our Constitution vs carrying out human rights violations or policies that are illegal when read within the framework of our Constitution, they will be fired. This is abhorrent to me and is highly un-American. 

We have a separation of the branches in government for just these reasons, to prevent the accumulation of all the power being in the hands of one person. This power needs to remain withn an organization or the two other equal branches.

This rule change should not happen. As an American citizen, I put my voice here, to say NO. The President needs to go through the proper channels (ie Congress or the Courts) to attempt to alter these policies and implement such wide-sweeping rule changes. 

If he does this, I'm confident the people will speak up again, and say no there, as well.

Thank you for taking my voice into consideration and I hope you will heed what Americans are asking for regarding this rule change, and in a larger picture: to uphold the Constitution.

title: Comment from Randal Lewins
comment:
OPM's proposed dismissal of reliance interests in Section E regarding "Schedule Policy/Career" employees (removing 5 U.S.C. Ch. 43/75 protections) is legally unsound and undermines core civil service principles. OPM initially recognized valid reliance interests: employees' settled expectations based on statutory entitlements (Cleveland Bd. of Educ. v. Loudermill, 470 U.S. 532), public/Congressional interest in a non-partisan, expert workforce, and regulatory stability.

The assertion that these concerns are "misplaced" or prejudice is "small" fails scrutiny.

 * Fallacy of "Small" Prejudice: Removing established due process rights (notice, response, appeal) fundamentally alters employment nature from merit-based to potentially at-will, contradicting settled expectations derived from statute. This is not "small."

 * Mischaracterized Reliance Interest: The true interest is in procedural due process (5 U.S.C. §§ 7513, 7701) against arbitrary or pretextual removal—including retaliation for unwelcome expert advice—not, as OPM wrongly claims, an "ability to violate merit principles." Existing rules already address poor performance/misconduct.

 * Ignoring Chilling Effect/Censorship Risk: Removing appeals creates a chilling effect. Vague standards ("injecting personal politics") invite subjective misuse, silencing employees who offer candid, evidence-based advice differing from political preferences. This harms effective governance and risks censoring legitimate dissent or warnings about policy flaws. Assurances against politicization ring hollow without independent review.

 * Undermining CSRA & Merit Principles: The proposal upsets the balance struck by the Civil Service Reform Act of 1978 (CSRA), weakening Merit System Principles (5 U.S.C. § 2301(b), esp. Principles 1 & 2) and protections against Prohibited Personnel Practices (§ 2302), particularly political coercion or arbitrary action.

 * Improper Deference: OPM's stated deference to Presidential cost-benefit analysis over its independent statutory duty (5 U.S.C. § 1103) to uphold the merit system framework established by Congress is inappropriate.

Proposed Revisions to Mitigate Risks:

To prevent censorship of good-faith policy disagreement and protect expert advice:

 * Retain Ch. 43/75 Protections: Best solution. Address performance/misconduct via existing processes.

 * Narrowly Define Scope: If schedule proceeds, restrict strictly to high-level, final policy decision-makers, excluding advisory/analytical roles.

 * Clarify Removal Standards: Replace vague terms with objective criteria focused on misconduct/performance failure, explicitly excluding good-faith advice/analysis offered through proper channels.

 * Protect Professional Judgment: Add safeguards (e.g., via § 2302(b)) explicitly protecting employees from adverse action based on the substance of good-faith professional judgment or analysis.

 * Maintain Independent Review: Retain meaningful, independent review (even if modified) to verify cause and prevent pretextual removals.


OPM's rationale in Section E is flawed and dangerous to the non-partisan, expert civil service. It minimizes statutory rights, misrepresents employee interests, ignores chilling effects, and contravenes the CSRA's intent. OPM should withdraw this harmful proposal or substantially revise it to preserve essential procedural safeguards against politicization and censorship, ensuring government effectiveness and accountability.

title: Comment from Rich Furman
comment:
I am writing to express my concern over OPM-2025-0004, or as it is rather deceptively called "Improving Performance, Accountability and Responsiveness in the Civil Service." The concern, it seems, is that Civil Service employees are not subject to the vagaries of hiring and firing suffered by "at will" employees.  This is a feature, not a bug. It is designed to ensure continuity of service in essential government functions, giving the taxpayers confidence that the services for which they pay will be effectively administered.  The introduction of a "Schedule F" status strikes at the root of government stability.

We have already seen the abuse of probationary status for employees with less experience across the board of taxpayer facing services, leading to longer hold times with services that citizens actually use, delays in getting Social Security, failures of aid to reach people experiencing disasters, and a general reduction in overall reliability.

Introducing another tool to allow the further destabilization of government function and replace its staff with a cadre of inexperienced neophytes does more to hurt the safety and security of the American People. Americans do not need the further destabilization of their lives that this proposal would facilitate.

title: Comment from Kelly Ross
comment:
As friends and supporters of federal employees, we are submitting this comment to express concern about the proposed creation of Schedule Policy/Career and the harmful impact it may have on the career civil service.



We understand the goal of this rule is to promote accountability and responsiveness in government. However, we believe the rule as written is too broad and puts hard-working public servants at risk of losing their due process rights, even if their jobs have nothing to do with policy-making or political decision-making.



Many federal employees work in roles such as data analysis, public benefits processing, casework, training, operations, finance, HR, or technical program support. These are not policy positions. Yet we have heard troubling reports that entire lists of employees are being considered for reclassification under this new schedule—even those whose work has nothing to do with shaping or influencing federal policy.



This raises several concerns:

1. Risk of Wrongful Reclassification



The proposed rule lacks a clear mechanism for verifying whether a job is truly policy-influencing. There is no requirement that the official position description contain language such as “policy-making” or “policy-determining,” despite 5 U.S.C. § 7511(b)(2) limiting exemption from adverse action protections only to those roles. Without this linkage, agencies may reclassify individuals based on assumptions or proximity to policy—not on actual duties. This lack of guardrails leaves OPM vulnerable to implementing the rule in a manner inconsistent with the statutory language.

2. Loss of Basic Workplace Protections



Employees reclassified into Schedule Policy/Career would lose appeal rights under Chapters 43 and 75, even if removed for pretextual or retaliatory reasons. While the proposal states that removals may not be politically motivated, there is no independent enforcement or redress mechanism provided to ensure fairness. A non-political civil service requires more than intent—it requires due process.

3. Impact on the Public



Federal employees are the people who process veterans’ benefits, issue immigration documents, manage public lands, and oversee safety regulations. Disrupting their stability with vague classifications and at-will removals will ultimately reduce the quality and timeliness of services provided to the American public.

4. Potential for Political Abuse



Removing long-standing civil service protections creates a slippery slope toward politicization, especially if roles are misclassified without oversight. It risks undoing over a century of reforms designed to insulate public servants from political pressure and retribution.

What OPM Should Do



We urge OPM to revise the proposed rule to:

Define “policy-influencing” using the actual position description language, requiring reference to policy development, regulatory discretion, or executive direction.

Exclude operational, analytical, and support positions that do not meet that threshold.

Prohibit bulk reclassification via personnel lists and instead require individual position-by-position justifications.

Create a redress mechanism for employees who believe they were wrongly classified or removed.

Publish aggregate data on reclassification activity to maintain public transparency.

Substantiated Concern for Agency Response (APA Compliance)



The current rule lacks a clear, operational definition of “policy-influencing” tied to official position descriptions, yet uses that term as the legal basis for exempting employees from adverse action protections under 5 U.S.C. § 7511(b)(2). Courts have previously required that such exceptions be applied narrowly (see Fausto, 484 U.S. 439 (1988)). If OPM proceeds without enforcing an objective PD-based standard, it may violate its own statutory authority and expose the agency to future legal challenges or inconsistent application across agencies. OPM must address this definitional gap to ensure lawful implementation.

In Closing



We support accountability. But federal public servants deserve fair treatment—not vague reclassification standards and sudden loss of rights. We urge OPM to revise the rule to reflect constitutional principles, operational needs, and the values of a nonpartisan civil service.



Thank you for the opportunity to comment.

Disrupting their stability with vague classifications and at-will removals will ultimately reduce the quality and timeliness of services provided to the American public.

4. Potential for Political Abuse



Removing long-standing civil service protections creates a slippery slope toward politicization, especially if roles are misclassified without oversight. It risks undoing over a century of reforms designed to insulate public servants from political pressure and retribution.

What OPM Should Do



We urge OPM to revise the proposed rule to:

Define “policy-influencing” using the actual position description language, requiring reference to policy development, regulatory discretion, or executive direction.

Exclude operational, analytical, and support positions that do not meet that threshold.

Prohibit bulk reclassification via personnel lists and instead require individual position-by-position justifications.

Create a redress mechanism for employees who believe they were wrongly classified or removed.

Publish aggregate data on reclassification activity to maintain public transparency.

Substantiated Concern for Agency Response (APA Compliance)



The current rule lacks a clear, operational definition of “policy-influencing” tied to official position descriptions, yet uses that term as the legal basis for exempting employees from adverse action protections under 5 U.S.C. § 7511(b)(2). Courts have previously required that such exceptions be applied narrowly (see Fausto, 484 U.S. 439 (1988)). If OPM proceeds without enforcing an objective PD-based standard, it may violate its own statutory authority and expose the agency to future legal challenges or inconsistent application across agencies. OPM must address this definitional gap to ensure lawful implementation.

In Closing



We support accountability. But federal public servants deserve fair treatment—not vague reclassification standards and sudden loss of rights. We urge OPM to revise the rule to reflect constitutional principles, operational needs, and the values of a nonpartisan civil service.



Thank you for the opportunity to comment.

title: Comment from Dale  Van Dusen
comment:
Public Comment Opposing the Reinstatement of Schedule F

I write to strongly oppose the proposed reinstatement or expansion of Schedule F, which would undermine the merit-based principles that have guided the federal civil service for over a century. This proposal is not only contrary to the foundational values of a nonpartisan federal workforce but also threatens the continuity, competence, and integrity of government operations.

The merit system, codified in the Civil Service Reform Act of 1978, was designed to ensure that hiring and firing decisions in the federal workforce are based on competence, not political loyalty. Reintroducing Schedule F would effectively reverse these protections, placing tens of thousands of career civil servants at risk of politically motivated termination. This undermines the principle of a government that serves the people impartially, irrespective of the political party in power. Historically, the move away from the patronage system—especially following the Pendleton Act of 1883—was a key advancement in professionalizing the civil service and ensuring effective governance.

The implementation of Schedule F would open the door to politicizing crucial policy roles, destabilizing agencies, and discouraging skilled professionals from public service. America’s resilience depends on a trusted, nonpartisan civil service capable of withstanding political transitions. The federal workforce deserves the stability and fairness promised by existing civil service protections. I urge the administration to abandon any effort to resurrect Schedule F and instead reaffirm its commitment to a professional, impartial civil service grounded in merit and accountability.

title: Comment from Ryan Tyndelson
comment:
This comment responds to Section E ("Reliance Interests") of the proposed rule and fundamental deficiencies in OPM's administrative process under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and potential overreach of OPM statutory authority.

 * Failure to Provide Reasoned Explanation for Policy Reversal (APA § 706(2)(A)): OPM's current proposal represents a stark reversal of its previously stated position, which acknowledged the validity and importance of employee, public, Congressional, and regulated entity reliance interests in the stability and procedural fairness afforded by Chapters 43 and 75. Under established administrative law, an agency changing its position must, at minimum, "display awareness that it is changing position" and "show that there are good reasons for the new policy." FCC v. Fox Television Stations, Inc., 556 U.S. 502, 515 (2009). The explanation provided in Section E – asserting concerns are "largely misplaced" and prejudice is "small" – is conclusory. It fails to provide a detailed, evidence-based analysis explaining why its prior assessment of these significant reliance interests was erroneous or why the newly asserted "policy benefits" so clearly outweigh them now when they did not before. This lack of reasoned explanation renders the reversal arbitrary and capricious.

 * Arbitrary Cost-Benefit Analysis and Lack of Evidentiary Support (APA § 706(2)(A)): The determination that reliance interests are "outweighed by the policy benefits" requires a rational balancing based on evidence. OPM asserts harms like "poor performance, misconduct, corruption, and career employees injecting partisanship," but provides no empirical evidence demonstrating: (a) the prevalence of these issues specifically among policy-influencing employees that cannot be addressed under existing Chapter 43/75 procedures, and (b) how removing appeal rights for this group is a proportionate and effective remedy directly tailored to these specific harms. Agencies must "examine the relevant data and articulate a satisfactory explanation for its action including a ‘rational connection between the facts found and the choice made.’" Motor Vehicle Mfrs. Ass'n v. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co., 463 U.S. 29, 43 (1983) (citation omitted). Simply declaring that the "necessity of a competent, ethical, and democratically accountable government" subordinates reliance interests, without demonstrating how this specific rule change achieves those aims more effectively than the existing system, and without quantifying or substantiating the alleged harms being remedied, constitutes an arbitrary and unsupported conclusion. Furthermore, OPM fails to adequately consider the substantial costs associated with its proposal, such as loss of institutional knowledge, increased recruitment challenges for expert roles, and erosion of trust within the workforce.

 * Exceeding Delegated Statutory Authority (Title 5, U.S. Code): OPM's authority to regulate the civil service (e.g., under 5 U.S.C. §§ 1103, 1301-02, 3301-02) must be exercised within the framework established by Congress. Congress explicitly defined the scope of adverse action appeal rights in Chapter 75, specifying which employees are covered (5 U.S.C. § 7511) and providing limited, specific exceptions (e.g., probationary periods, certain agencies/positions). The proposed rule effectively creates a broad new functional exception for "policy-influencing" roles within the competitive service, removing them from Chapter 75 protections. It is highly questionable whether OPM's general rulemaking authority extends to carving out such a significant portion of the career workforce from statutory protections explicitly granted by Congress, based on vaguely defined job duties rather than clear statutory language. This action appears less like administering the law and more like rewriting it, infringing upon legislative prerogative.

 * Major Questions Doctrine Implications: The proposed creation of Schedule Policy/Career represents a fundamental restructuring of the federal civil service with vast economic and political significance, potentially affecting tens or hundreds of thousands of employees and altering the balance between political appointees and career staff. Such a "transformative expansion" of executive control over the career workforce, significantly impacting a long-standing statutory scheme, implicates the Major Questions Doctrine. Under this doctrine, agencies asserting power over issues of major significance typically require clear, explicit authorization from Congress. West Virginia v. EPA, 597 U.S. 697 (2022). OPM cannot assume that its general administrative authority implicitly grants it the power to make such a fundamental change to the civil service system established by the CSRA without clear Congressional direction.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
The existence of the Federal Civil Service in its current form was a specific response to the problems created by the very sort of things this proposal is designed to provide. Cronyism and patronage creates a sycophantic civil service that lacks expertise and punishes expertise and candid advice, the sorts of things a functional civil service means to provide. It also safeguards against corruption and bribery, both in the awarding of positions and in day-to-day operation. A civil servant with career protections has incentive to refuse unethical activity and to adhere to constitutional requirements, as losing a long-term safe employment is usually not worth a quick buck.

Further, while the proposed rule claims that these positions will be "non partisan" and "non political", that is demonstrably false. Even if that were to be pursued in good faith initially, the temptation to dismiss now at-will employees for political reasons will be acted upon, as history has always shown. I think it is wise for anyone seriously considering this proposal to do some research into why the civil service system limiting political positions and protecting other positions exists; it's not a pretty story.

I am under no illusions that this comment will be read, internalized, or responded to in good faith. Those who wrote this don't want a better civil service; they want more positions they can stuff underqualified political drones into so they can reward political supporters free of senate approval and clear out anyone willing to offer opinions contrary to the groupthink of the political operatives. A civil service open to free and open debate in policy and enforcement areas is going to be far more effective than the echo chamber of unqualified yes-men this proposal will create. If this change is going to be made, it should be made by Congress.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
I respectfully submit this formal comment in opposition to the proposed rule titled “Improving Performance, Accountability and Responsiveness in the Civil Service” (Docket ID: OPM-2025-0004-0001). While accountability in government is important, this rule undermines core legal and institutional safeguards that ensure the federal workforce remains competent, impartial, and protected from political abuse.

The proposed creation of a “Schedule Policy/Career” category—functionally similar to the rescinded Schedule F—would strip civil servants of their due process rights and convert large portions of the workforce into at-will employees. This directly conflicts with the Civil Service Reform Act of 1978 (5 U.S.C. §§ 2301, 2302), which protects employees from retaliation, political coercion, and arbitrary dismissal.

This rule politicizes public service by targeting policy-related positions and risks returning us to a spoils system long rejected by American governance. Institutions such as the Congressional Research Service, the Government Accountability Office, and the National Academy of Public Administration have warned against such moves. Public trust, operational stability, and the attractiveness of federal service would all be diminished.

The rule also contradicts foundational American principles—justice, neutrality, and the rule of law—by turning federal employment into a loyalty test. As noted by Columbia Law Professor Peter Strauss, these reforms would undermine the Constitution’s vision of neutral competence in government.

For these reasons, I urge OPM to withdraw the proposed rule. A full version of my comment with legal citations and supporting evidence is attached as a PDF.




--- ATTACHMENTS ---

[ATTACHMENT: attachment_1.pdf]
April 23, 2025
U.S. Office of Personnel Management
Attn: Regulatory Affairs Division
1900 E Street, NW
Washington, DC 20415
Subject: Formal Comment Opposing Docket ID: OPM-2025-0004-0001
To Whom It May Concern,
I am writing to express my unequivocal opposition to the proposed rule titled "Improving
Performance, Accountability and Responsiveness in the Civil Service" (Docket ID:
OPM-2025-0004-0001). While enhancing performance and accountability in government
is a worthy objective, this proposal is legally questionable, substantively harmful,
historically regressive, and fundamentally contrary to American ideals of fairness, justice,
and the rule of law.
Erosion of Due Process and Merit System Protections
This proposal seeks to create a new “Schedule Policy/Career” classification that would
strip federal employees of due process rights and render them at-will employees. This
undermines core protections enshrined in the Civil Service Reform Act of 1978 (5 U.S.C.
§ 2301, § 2302), which prohibits removals based on political affiliation, whistleblowing,
or personal bias.
The merit system principles—long regarded as a bulwark against politicized
governance—would be dismantled in favor of a structure allowing for arbitrary removals.
These changes mirror the rescinded Executive Order 13957, which created Schedule F
and was met with bipartisan condemnation. Its subsequent revocation by Executive Order
14003 reaffirmed the importance of an apolitical, merit-based workforce.
Politicization of the Federal Workforce
By enabling reclassification and removal of policy-adjacent employees based on
subjective determinations, the rule invites a return to a spoils system—an approach
America abandoned with the Pendleton Act of 1883. The United States has long
maintained a professional civil service to ensure continuity and competence across
administrations. Reinstating an at-will structure for thousands of federal roles undermines
this nonpartisan tradition and raises the risk of mass purges motivated by ideology rather
than performance.
In 2020, the Congressional Research Service (CRS) warned that Schedule F-type reforms
would “severely erode civil service protections and could politicize up to tens of
thousands of federal positions.” Public interest organizations such as the Partnership for
Public Service, American Federation of Government Employees (AFGE), and National
Academy of Public Administration (NAPA) issued similar warnings.
Contrary to American Democratic Ideals
The proposed rule contradicts foundational American values—justice, impartiality, and
constitutional governance. The American ideal is a government that serves the people,
not a political faction. An independent civil service is essential to that goal. By replacing
merit-based employment with political loyalty tests, the rule invites corruption,
suppresses dissent, and weakens the institutional checks that underpin our republic.
As Professor Peter Strauss of Columbia Law School aptly observed in 2020, Schedule F-
style proposals are "an invitation to create a spoils system that violates the fundamental
American principle of neutral competence in government." These changes align more
closely with authoritarian regimes than with democratic governance.
Empirical Evidence of Harm
Historical and international evidence demonstrates that politicized bureaucracies perform
worse and suffer greater instability. The OECD 2020 Government at a Glance Report
ranks the U.S. civil service among the most professional and impartial globally.
Weakening these protections would reduce effectiveness and public trust.
According to a 2021 Government Accountability Office (GAO) report, impartiality in
federal employment is essential to safeguarding whistleblowers, rooting out corruption,
and maintaining public accountability. The Council of the Inspectors General on Integrity
and Efficiency (CIGIE) has repeatedly emphasized the importance of employment
protections in ensuring oversight and ethical conduct.
Operational and Human Capital Risks
Subjecting federal employees to at-will status introduces operational instability and
severely harms recruitment and retention. The 2020 Schedule F initiative was estimated
to impact over 50,000 employees. If revived under this rule, the scope could expand even
further, threatening institutional memory, workforce morale, and mission readiness.
Civil servants are already facing threats to job security amid growing polarization. This
rule will exacerbate that instability, making federal careers less attractive to future public
servants—particularly those with the technical expertise and integrity that modern
governance demands.
Conclusion
This proposal does not promote accountability; it erodes institutional integrity,
undermines constitutional principles, and invites politicization at the expense of public
trust. The United States deserves a government staffed by professionals who are
empowered to speak truthfully, serve impartially, and uphold their oath to the
Constitution without fear of political retaliation.
I strongly urge OPM to withdraw this proposal in its entirety. The future of American
governance—and the legitimacy of our civil service—depends on it.
Sincerely,
“A Concerned Citizen and Public Servant (Name withheld for safety and privacy)”

I respectfully submit this formal comment in opposition to the proposed rule titled “Improving Performance, Accountability and Responsiveness in the Civil Service” (Docket ID: OPM-2025-0004-0001). While accountability in government is important, this rule undermines core legal and institutional safeguards that ensure the federal workforce remains competent, impartial, and protected from political abuse.

The proposed creation of a “Schedule Policy/Career” category—functionally similar to the rescinded Schedule F—would strip civil servants of their due process rights and convert large portions of the workforce into at-will employees. This directly conflicts with the Civil Service Reform Act of 1978 (5 U.S.C. §§ 2301, 2302), which protects employees from retaliation, political coercion, and arbitrary dismissal.

This rule politicizes public service by targeting policy-related positions and risks returning us to a spoils system long rejected by American governance. Institutions such as the Congressional Research Service, the Government Accountability Office, and the National Academy of Public Administration have warned against such moves. Public trust, operational stability, and the attractiveness of federal service would all be diminished.

The rule also contradicts foundational American principles—justice, neutrality, and the rule of law—by turning federal employment into a loyalty test. As noted by Columbia Law Professor Peter Strauss, these reforms would undermine the Constitution’s vision of neutral competence in government.

For these reasons, I urge OPM to withdraw the proposed rule. A full version of my comment with legal citations and supporting evidence is attached as a PDF.

title: Comment from Steven Mendler
comment:
Thank you for reviewing these comments. Respectfully, this proposed rule making action should be rejected due to fundamental incompatibility with the enforcement architecture of the Civil Service Reform Act of 1978 (CSRA) and its disruption of the exclusive statutory framework governing performance and conduct-based adverse actions. I've outlined several reasons below why the proposed action is untenable for OPM to pursue further.

 * Nullification of Prohibited Personnel Practice (PPP) Enforcement: A cornerstone of the CSRA is the protection against PPPs (5 U.S.C. § 2302(b)). For covered employees facing major adverse actions, the primary forum for vindicating these rights—particularly challenging actions potentially based on political affiliation (§ 2302(b)(1)(E)), reprisal for whistleblowing (§ 2302(b)(8)), or reprisal for exercising appeal rights (§ 2302(b)(9))—is through an appeal to the Merit Systems Protection Board (MSPB) under Chapter 75. Removing MSPB appeal rights for "Schedule Policy/Career" employees effectively neutralizes this vital enforcement mechanism for the very group often most vulnerable to political pressure or retaliation related to policy execution. This eviscerates a key check Congress established against politicization, leaving statutory prohibitions as rights without effective remedies in the context of removal or demotion. Reliance on the Office of Special Counsel alone is not a substitute for direct, individual appeal rights with independent adjudication.

 * Circumvention of Exclusive Statutory Schemes (Chapters 43 & 75): Congress deliberately established Chapters 43 and 75 of Title 5 as the detailed, comprehensive, and exclusive statutory procedures for addressing unacceptable performance and misconduct (or other cause) for covered career employees. These chapters reflect specific legislative choices regarding grounds for action, procedural requirements (notice, opportunity to respond), burden of proof, and independent review. The proposed rule creates a parallel, non-statutory removal track based on ill-defined functional criteria ("policy-influencing") and subjective standards ("confidence," "alignment"). This constitutes an impermissible attempt by OPM to bypass the exclusive remedial schemes mandated by Congress, effectively allowing agencies to remove employees for reasons or via processes not sanctioned by the controlling statutes. It violates the principle that where Congress has enacted a specific, comprehensive remedial scheme, agency action must adhere to that scheme.

 * Undermining the CSRA's Integrated Design: The CSRA created an integrated system balancing management needs with robust employee protections enforced through MSPB review. This structure was intended to prevent the very type of politically convenient removals facilitated by the proposed rule. By exempting a large group from MSPB oversight based on regulatory redefinition rather than statutory amendment, OPM fractures this integrated design. It selectively removes the element (independent appeal) intended to ensure the system operates based on merit and law, not political favor or policy conformity.

 * Implicit Reliance on Non-Statutory Removal Authority: The rationale implies agencies need authority to remove employees in these roles for reasons other than those specified and actionable under Chapters 43/75 (i.e., lack of "confidence" untethered to misconduct or performance). OPM fails to identify any statutory basis for such broad, subjective removal authority over career competitive service employees whom Congress explicitly placed under Chapter 75's protections (5 U.S.C. § 7511(a)(1)(A)). Asserting this authority via regulation contradicts the statutory framework.

In sum, the proposed rule's dismissal of reliance interests ignores the reliance on the CSRA's enforcement mechanisms and statutory exclusivity. By crippling PPP enforcement through MSPB appeals and circumventing the specific procedures mandated by Congress in Chapters 43 and 75, the rule fundamentally conflicts with the controlling statutory law. This constitutes legal flaw warranting the proposal's rejection. Should the president believe such reforms are necessary, he is permitted to lobby for the requisite authority on the Hill and this alone is the correct vehicle for achieving these modifications.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
I am writing to express strong opposition to the Office of Personnel Management’s (OPM) proposed rule OPM-2025-0004-0001, which seeks to reclassify approximately 50,000 federal employees into a newly designated Schedule Policy/Career (P/C) category. This proposal, a revival of the previously rescinded Schedule F, threatens the foundational principles of a nonpartisan, merit-based civil service and poses significant risks to the integrity, efficiency, and accountability of federal operations.

Erosion of Merit-Based Protections

The cornerstone of the federal civil service is its commitment to merit-based hiring and retention, ensuring that employment decisions are grounded in qualifications and performance rather than political affiliation. By reclassifying positions into Schedule P/C, the proposed rule would strip affected employees of critical protections against arbitrary dismissal, effectively making them at-will employees. This undermines the Civil Service Reform Act of 1978, which was enacted to prevent politicization and ensure a competent and impartial federal workforce.

Increased Risk of Politicization

The reintroduction of Schedule P/C opens the door to replacing experienced, nonpartisan professionals with individuals selected for their political loyalty rather than expertise. Such a shift could compromise the objectivity of policy analysis and implementation, leading to decisions that serve partisan interests over the public good. The National Active and Retired Federal Employees Association (NARFE) has rightly noted that this move "opens the door to replacing nonpartisan, professional civil servants with political loyalists".

Undermining Institutional Knowledge and Continuity

Federal agencies rely on the institutional knowledge and continuity provided by career civil servants. Reclassifying positions and removing job protections could lead to a loss of experienced personnel, disrupting agency operations and diminishing the government's ability to effectively serve the public. The potential for mass dismissals based on political considerations threatens the stability and effectiveness of federal programs.

Legal and Ethical Concerns

The proposed rule raises serious legal and ethical questions. The previous iteration, Schedule F, faced legal challenges and was ultimately rescinded due to concerns about its legality and potential for abuse. Reintroducing a similar framework disregards these concerns and may once again lead to protracted legal battles, diverting resources and attention from the government's primary responsibilities.

Conclusion

The proposed reclassification of federal positions into Schedule Policy/Career represents a significant departure from the principles that have long safeguarded the integrity and effectiveness of the federal workforce. It threatens to politicize the civil service, erode merit-based protections, and disrupt the continuity of government operations. I urge OPM to withdraw this proposed rule and instead focus on strengthening the existing merit-based system that ensures a competent, impartial, and stable federal workforce.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
I urge the administration and the Office of Personnel Management to abandon any effort to create or reinstate a “Schedule F” category within the federal workforce. Such a reclassification would corrode the very qualities its title—“Improving Performance, Accountability and Responsiveness in the Civil Service”—claims to uphold. In truth, by turning policy advisors and career experts into at-will employees, the rule would sap institutional knowledge, chill candid analysis, and substitute political loyalty for professional competence—precisely the opposite of better performance, real accountability, or genuine responsiveness.

Such a reclassification would erode the merit‐based framework established by the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883, which replaced patronage with a system that rewards skill and performance rather than political allegiance. By designating policy analysts and other career professionals as “at-will” employees, Schedule F would grant political appointees sweeping authority to remove long-serving experts without cause—undermining the very impartiality and stability our government depends on.

Schedule F also conflicts directly with the statutory mandate in 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq., which charges the Office of Personnel Management with upholding the merit system principles. Converting scientific advisors, program managers, and rule-writers into political hires would subject them to constant pressure to conform to short-term agendas, putting continuity and institutional knowledge at risk with each change in leadership.

In short, adopting Schedule F would represent a fundamental departure from the nonpartisan, professional civil service that has served our nation for over a century. It would disassemble tried-and-true checks on political favoritism, diminish accountability, and weaken public trust. I respectfully call on decision-makers to preserve the integrity of the civil service by rejecting any proposal to implement or revive Schedule F.
